revision.text:
'''Citizenship education''' for new citizens is education intended to prepare noncitizens to become legally and socially accepted as [[citizens]], and is carried out by a variety of governmental and non-governmental organizations ([[NGO]]).
==Belgium== An integration programme is organised in the [[Flanders|Flemish Region]] of Belgium. The programma is obliged in many cases and consists of an "integration course" (citizenship education) a basic level Dutch course, and career orientation. It is also possible to enroll in the programme in [[Brussels]], without any obligation. ==Germany== In order to obtain German citizenship it is compulsory for a citizen to pass an "Integrationkurs" - which teaches the basics of the [[German language]] and German culture and society, such as the German legal system, history and culture, rights and obligations in Germany etc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bamf.de/EN/Willkommen/DeutschLernen/Integrationskurse/InhaltAblauf/inhaltablauf-node.html;jsessionid=CA02CE883966C546DAFBFB4EFAD0F913.1_cid286|title=BAMF - Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge - Content and scheduling|website=www.bamf.de|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> ==Netherlands== In the Netherlands the citizen education for new citizens is called "inburgeringsplicht" (see [[Integration law for new immigrants to the Netherlands]]). In many cases the foreigner is obliged to learn very basic Dutch and basic knowledge about Dutch society while still abroad and he or she must pass an exam abroad before receiving a visa for temporary residence. All this depends on certain criteria (especially what country the foreigner comes from).<ref>[http://www.ind.nl/en/inbedrijf/wonenenwerken/basisexamen15maart.asp Civic integration examination abroad introduced] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101216165323/http://ind.nl/en/inbedrijf/wonenenwerken/basisexamen15maart.asp |date=2010-12-16 }} website of [[Immigratie en Naturalisatiedienst]] retrieved 2010-April-24</ref>
==United States== In the late 19th and early 20th centuries in the [United States], government programs prepared [[immigrant]]s to take citizenship exams or qualify for citizenship. Many corporations, most prominently [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], offered similar programs to their employees and families of their employees. In addition, various charities also provided this service.
==United Kingdom== In the [[United Kingdom]] in 2002, [[David Blunkett]] introduced a series of proposals where immigrants would take a written "test" and participate in a ceremony before they could be granted British nationality. Before being given a passport, applicants read [[Life in the United Kingdom]] (a book providing information about the UK), prepare for and sit a 45-minute test on British society, history and culture.
== See also == * [[Home Office]] * [[Immigration and Nationality Directorate]] * [[UK Visas and Immigration]] * [[Integrationskurs]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070410021652/http://www.uknationality.gov.uk/ UK Border Agency]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Citizenship Education}} [[Category:Educational programs]] [[Category:Immigration law]]

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
{{Infobox economist | name = Claudia Goldin | school_tradition = | color = | image = 2008 Claudia Goldin.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1946|05|14}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | institution = [[Harvard University]]
[[National Bureau of Economic Research|NBER]] | field = [[Labor economics]]
[[Economic History]] | alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
[[University of Chicago]] ([[Master of Arts|M.A.]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]]) | influences = | influenced = | contributions = | website = https://scholar.harvard.edu/goldin | awards = [[IZA Prize in Labor Economics]] (2016) | signature = | repec_prefix = f | repec_id = pgo601 }} '''Claudia Goldin''' (born May 14, 1946) is the Henry Lee Professor of Economics at [[Harvard University]] and director of the Development of the American Economy program at the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]]. Goldin was the president of the [[American Economic Association]] in 2013–14 and winner of the 2016 IZA Prize in Labor Economics "for her career-long work on the economic history of women in education and the labor market."{{cite web|title=IZA Prize in Labor Economics|url=http://legacy.iza.org/en/webcontent/prize/iza_prize|publisher=IZA – Institute of Labor Economics|accessdate=28 June 2017|date=2016}} In 1990, she became the first woman to be tenured at the Harvard economics department. ==Education and work== Goldin was born in [[New York City]] in 1946. She attended the [[Bronx High School of Science]] and [[Cornell University]] and completed her doctorate in economics at the [[University of Chicago]] in 1972.[[Janet Zollinger Giele]] and Leslie F. Stebbins. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CdCjACqXU4wC&pg=PA179 ''Women and Equality In the Workplace: A Reference Handbook'']. Santa Barbara, Calif.: ABC-CLIO, 2003, {{ISBN|978-1-57607-937-9}}. Her research interests include [[economic history]], [[labor economics]], gender and economics, and the economics of work, family, and education. Some of her more recent papers include "The Quiet Revolution that Transformed Women's Employment, Education, and Family", which describes and analyses changes in female labor force participation over the past century, "The Homecoming of American College Women: The Reversal of the Gender Gap in College" (with [[Lawrence F. Katz]] and Ilyana Kuziemko), which probes the causes of the upsurge in women’s college attendance, and "A Pollution Theory of Discrimination: Male and Female Occupations and Earnings", which addresses [[gender pay gap|wage differentials]] between men and women. In 1990, Goldin became the first [[tenure]]d woman at Harvard's economics department.{{cite news|last1=Alexander|first1=Sophie M.|title=Goldin Demystifies Gender Economics|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2007/4/26/goldin-demystifies-gender-economics-gender-will/|work=[[The Harvard Crimson]]|date=April 26, 2007}} She collaborates frequently with [[Lawrence F. Katz]], a fellow economics professor at Harvard, who is a "[[Significant other|personal]] as well as research partner".{{cite news|last1=Jonas|first1=Michael|title=Learning curve|url=http://www.commonwealthmagazine.org/Voices/Conversation/2011/Fall/001-Learning-curve.aspx|work=CommonWealth magazine|issue=Fall 2011/American Dream Special Issue|date=November 3, 2011}} ==Scholarship== ===“Transitions: Career and Family Life Cycles of the Educational Elite” (2008)=== Goldin co-authored this article with Lawrence F. Katz. Goldin and Katz look into the transition of women getting married and bearing children at an older age, while becoming more educated and entering the workforce. Beginning in the 1970s, a surge of women began pursuing careers and foregoing getting married and having children in their early 20s. The median age at first marriage among college graduate women, which had been stable at about 22.5 years old from the 1950s to the early 1970s (for birth cohorts from the 1930s to about 1950), increased by 2.5 years between 1972 and 1979 (for birth cohorts from about 1950 to 1955). The fraction of women not having a first birth by around 40 years old increased from 20 percent for those graduating in the early 1960s, to 28 percent for those graduating in the 1970s. College graduate women greatly increased their education in professional schools; the fraction female among first-year law and medical school students, for example, was 10 percent in 1970 but rose to 40 percent by 1990. Goldin provides a detailed account of women at Harvard University in the years 1970, 1980, and 1990 within the study. It showed a great increase in the percentage of female students, and a significant decrease in the percentage of female students who were married two years after receiving their degree. Though more female students entered the University, and they did not get married right away, the percentage of the female graduates who work full-time, full year from the 1990 class is 1.7 percent lower than those from 1970.{{Cite web|url=http://scholar.harvard.edu/files/lkatz/files/transitions_career_and_family_lifecycles_of_the_educational_elite.pdf|title=Transitions: Career and Family Life Cycles of the Educational Elite|last=Goldin|first=Claudia|date=2008|website=Harvard University|publisher=American Economic Review|access-date=}} ==="The Quiet Revolution that Transformed Women's Employment, Education, and Family" (2006)=== The Quiet Revolution (1970s–present) was preceded by what Goldin labeled as three evolutionary phases: “Independent Female Worker” (late-19th century – 1920s), “Easing the Constraints on Married Women in the Labor Force” (1930s–1950), and “Roots of the Revolution” (1950s–1970s), respectively. In the first phase, the female workers were usually young and single, working in manufacturing or as domestics and laundresses. These women had little learning on the job and the majority of women were not well educated. Moving into the second phase, the labor factor productivity for married women increased by 15.5% because of an increased demand for office workers and the participation of women in the "[[high school movement]]". By the third phase, the female labor supply had become more [[Elasticity (economics)|elastic]] and more responsive to changes in wages. In this period, most women were secondary earners and worked in "[[Pink-collar worker|pink-collar]]" jobs as secretaries, teachers, nurses, social workers, and librarians. Even though higher education was possible, most women did not establish careers, and went to college to meet their spouses rather than to further their education. Goldin argues that the transformation in female labor force participation is due to changes in factors such as female horizons, identities, and average marrying age.{{cite journal|author1=Claudia Goldin|title=The Quiet Revolution That Transformed Women’s Employment, Education, and Family|journal=[[American Economic Review]]|date=2006|volume=96|issue=2|pages=1–21|doi=10.1257/000282806777212350|url=http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/000282806777212350}} In Goldin's article, the term "horizon" refers to how a woman perceives her lifetime labor force involvement at the time of human capital investment, and whether her involvement will be long-term or short-term. Identity refers to the individuality a woman finds in her job, occupation, or career. Lastly, decision-making entails whether a woman makes labor force decisions jointly if she is married or in a long-term relationship, or whether she takes a secondary position where time is allocated by her spouse's labor involvement decisions. What set the "Quiet Revolution" aside from the three evolutionary periods was that the revolution was a change marked from static decision-making to one of [[dynamic decision making]]. According to Goldin, a key cause of the Quiet Revolution was the development of new contraceptive technology, namely the [[birth control]] pill. Young women married and had children at a lower rate if the state they lived in had early legal access to it; women could set aside their relationships and pursue a career through higher education. Goldin and Katz noted that the birth control pill was approved by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] in 1960 for use by married women. It spread to young, unmarried women in the late 1960s with change in [[age of majority]] laws. Thus, they found a difference from the national average for women born 1930–1965 with if they lived in a state with early legal access to the pill. There was a −0.02 difference in marriage age at 23 from the national average of 0.41. There was a −0.07 difference from the national average of having a child by 22. There was a 0.004 difference from the national average of being a professional, and a 0.016 difference from the national average of being a lawyer or doctor. The birth control pill affected marriage, fertility, and career choice. ==="Decreasing (and then Increasing) Inequality in America: A Tale of Two Half-Centuries" (2001)=== Goldin co-authored this article with [[Lawrence F. Katz]]. In the article, Goldin and Katz divide the 20th century in the United States into two periods. The second half of the 20th century is considered a period of widening inequality, while the first half is a period of narrowing inequality. They examine, among other things, the “Great Compression” of wages in the 1940s and education reforms such as the [[high school movement]] in the 1900s.{{cite book |chapter= Decreasing (and then Increasing) Inequality in America: A Tale of Two Half-Centuries|chapterurl= http://scholar.harvard.edu/goldin/files/decreasing_and_then_increasing.pdf|editor1-last=Welch|editor1-first=Finis|title=The Causes and Consequences of Increasing Inequality|date=2001|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, IL|isbn=9780226893013|pages=37–82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0wUravsiZ4cC&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} ==="The Human Capital Century and American Leadership: Virtues of the Past" (2001)=== In the 20th century human capital investment became generally regarded by industrialized nations as being more important than technology and physical capital investment. This article queries the reasons the United States invested in human capital through post-elementary education to a far greater extent than other wealthy nations at the time.{{cite journal|author1=Claudia Goldin|title=The Human Capital Century and American Leadership: Virtues of the Past|journal=Journal of Economic History|date=June 2001|volume=61|issue=2|pages=263–292|doi=10.1017/S0022050701028017|url=http://scholar.harvard.edu/goldin/publications/human-capital-century-and-american-leadership-virtues-past}} "The Human Capital Century" examines the ways that post-elementary education in the United States during the 20th century was advanced, and argues that the principal reasons for U.S. education advancement were an ethic of [[egalitarianism]] (as opposed to elite educational systems in many European countries) and initial factor endowments which led to liberal education instead of vocational education, a high level of return on post-elementary education, geographic mobility, and a decentralized educational system. Virtues contributing to the American educational template included public funding, openness, local control, [[gender neutrality]], [[separation of church and state]], and an academic curriculum. The resulting “high school movement” incorporating these virtues produced a larger group of educated workers, enabled social and geographical mobility, and contributed to potential economic growth. In contrast, Europe’s educational template was determined by a centralized government and remained less open in the 1950s, focusing on providing technical training programs in the form of work-study arrangements for older teenagers. Goldin states that many of the virtues characterizing the American educational system in the earlier part of the twentieth century may now be considered vices of the present. Through the open and forgiving system that once created social and geographic mobility, now appears a lack of strict standards. High enrollment rates for high schools as evidence for America’s open educational system do not necessarily imply high-quality education. Furthermore, through the decentralized system in which local districts that compete for residents participate in educational investments that once fostered growth of schools may now lead to large differences in funding. Finally, the public funding that once allowed anyone to join and everyone to be on equal footing now presents discrepancies due to poor and rich towns. ===''The Race Between Education and Technology'' (2008)=== Co-authored with [[Lawrence F. Katz]], Goldin explores the United States' economic slowdown in the late 1970s. They argue that it was rising [[Income inequality in the United States|economic inequality]] at the end of the 20th century, not slow productivity growth nor [[Convergence (economics)|economic convergence]] between nations, that was at the root of the United States' economic trouble.Harvard University Press. [http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog/GOLRAC.html ''The Race between Education and Technology''], accessed September 6, 2011. ==Awards== *Carolyn Shaw Bell Award from the [[American Economic Association]]{{cite web |url=https://www.aeaweb.org/content/file?id=453|title=CLAUDIA GOLDIN NAMED THE RECIPIENT OF THE 2005 CAROLYN SHAW BELL AWARD}} *2008 R.R . Hawkins Award, The Professional and Scholarly Publishing Division of the [[Association of American Publishers]] *2009 The Richard A. Lester Award for the Outstanding Book in [[Industrial Relations]] and Labor Economics ==Selected works== *Goldin, Claudia Dale. ''Understanding the Gender Gap: An Economic History of American Women''. New York: Oxford University Press, 1990, {{ISBN|978-0-19-505077-6}}. *Goldin, Claudia Dale and [[Lawrence F. Katz]]. ''The Race Between Education and Technology''. Cambridge, Mass.: Belknap Press of Harvard University Press, 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-674-02867-8}}. *Glaeser, Edward L. and Claudia Dale Goldin. ''Corruption and Reform: Lessons from America’s History''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-226-29957-0}}. *Bordo, Michael D., Claudia Dale Goldin, and Eugene Nelson White. ''The Defining Moment: The Great Depression and the American Economy in the Twentieth Century''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1998, {{ISBN|978-0-226-06589-2}}. *Goldin, Claudia Dale and Gary D. Libecap. ''Regulated Economy: A Historical Approach to Political Economy''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1994, {{ISBN|978-0-226-30110-5}}. *Goldin, Claudia Dale et al. ''Strategic Factors in Nineteenth Century American Economic History: A Volume to Honor Robert W. Fogel''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1992, {{ISBN|978-0-226-30112-9}}. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://books.google.com/books?id=F8zynA594DUC&pg=PA98 ''The Economist as Detective''], a brief autobiographical essay by Claudia Goldin. In: M. Szenberg (ed.). ''Passion and Craft: Economists at Work''. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press, 1998, {{ISBN|978-0-472-09685-5}}. *[http://scholar.harvard.edu/goldin/publications Academic Papers] by Claudia Goldin. *[http://www.minneapolisfed.org/publications_papers/pub_display.cfm?id=3316 Interview] with Goldin by The Region of the Minneapolis Fed {{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{s-bef | before = [[Christopher A. Sims]]}} {{s-ttl | title = [[American Economic Association#Association presidents|President]] of the [[American Economic Association]] | years = 2013– 2014 }} {{s-aft | after = [[William Nordhaus]] }} {{s-end}} {{Presidents of the American Economic Association}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goldin, Claudia}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Cornell University alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:Economic historians]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:American women economists]] [[Category:Labor economists]] [[Category:Education economists]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Fellows of the Econometric Society]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Economic Association]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:21st-century economists]] [[Category:Distinguished Fellows of the American Economic Association]]

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
{{redirect|CBCO|the Orillia rebroadcaster of CBLA-FM|CBCO-FM}} [[Community organizing]] describes a wide variety of efforts to empower residents in a local area to participate in civic life or governmental affairs. Most efforts that claim this label operate in low-income or middle-income areas, and have adopted at least some of the tactics and organizing techniques pioneered by [[Saul Alinsky]] and his [[Industrial Areas Foundation]]. Other organizations in this tradition include [[PICO National Network]], [[Gamaliel Foundation]], and [[Direct Action and Research Training Center]] (DART).
They focus on building political power in the hands of an organization of local residents, and using that power to influence issues the organization defines as important. '''Congregation-based Community Organizing''' (CBCO) works through local [[synagogues]], [[church (building)|churches]], and [[mosques]] as the primary institutional sponsors of this work. Common characteristics:
*'''Faith-based:''' They ground their organizing in the moral values and traditions that stem from religious faith, to varying degrees and often quite powerfully. See [[religion and peacebuilding]]. *'''Broad-based:''' They are typically [[ecumenism|ecumenical]] or [[interfaith dialogue|interfaith]], and many include schools, unions, or a variety of other community-based institutions like neighborhood associations. *'''Locally constituted:''' They organize in areas that range from large neighborhoods to entire cities. Although linked into the national and regional networks discussed above, they emphasize local grassroots organizing. *'''Multi-issue:''' Their purpose is to instruct local congregational authorities about how to effectively address a variety of pressing issues facing their communities. *'''Professionally staffed:''' CBCO groups hire professionals to recruit and train leaders to work with their religious communities on a personal and regular basis.
==References== *[[Edward T. Chambers|Chambers, Edward T.]] and Michael A. Cowan, ''Roots for Radicals: Organizing for Power, Action, and Justice'' (New York: Continuum, 2003). {{ISBN|0-8264-1499-0}} *Jacobsen, Dennis A. 2001. ''Doing Justice: Congregations and Community Organizing''. Minneapolis: Fortress Press. *Wood, Richard L.[http://www.unm.edu/~rlwood] and Mark R. Warren. 2002. "A Different Face of Faith-Based Politics: Social Capital and Community Organizing in the Public Arena," ''International Journal of Sociology and Social Policy'', 22:11/12, 6-54 (Fall 2002).
==External links== *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dr3K8vxKw1c Congregation Based Community Organizing] Jewish Fund for Justice video (7:33). Rabbis and lay leaders share reflections on this justice work. *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WEcR6_D9Vtk: 4200 People at PICO Rally for Children's Health] coverage for the more than 800,000 children in California who are uninsured. Video (5:01)(April 2005).
[[Category:Community organizing]]

revision.comment: /* Alumni */
revision.text:
The '''Conservatorio Nacional Superior de Música''' is the [[music school|national music conservatory]] for Argentina and it is located in [[Buenos Aires]].
==History== Ernesto de la Guardia, a member of the Wagnerian Society of Buenos Aires, first proposed the creation of a national conservatory. He gained support from the [[president of Argentina|president]] [[Marcelo Torcuato de Alvear]] and his wife [[Regina Pacini]] a noted [[soprano]],<ref name="García">{{cite web|last1=García Cánepa|first1=Julio César|title=Institucional Historia|url=http://artesmusicales.org/web/index.php/institucional/historia.html|website=artesmusicales.org|publisher=Departamento de Artes Musicales y Sonoras “Carlos López Buchardo”|accessdate=4 July 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161201224531/http://artesmusicales.org/web/index.php/institucional/historia.html|archivedate=1 December 2016|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|language=Spanish|date=2012}}</ref> the ''Conservatorio Nacional de Música y Declamación'' (National Conservatory of Music and Recitation) was founded by Argentine musician [[Carlos López Buchardo]], among others, on July 7, 1924. Based upon the School of Lyric and Scenic Art held at the [[Teatro Colón]] in [[Buenos Aires]], the conservatory focused on both lyric and theatrical studies, providing instruction in composition, vocal and instrument music, recitation and speech.<ref name="Clasico" >{{cite web|title=Conservatorio Nacional de Música y Declamación|url=http://www.musicaclasicaargentina.com/conservatorio.htm|website=Musica clasica Argentina|accessdate=4 July 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310024313/http://www.musicaclasicaargentina.com/conservatorio.htm|archivedate=10 March 2016|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|language=Spanish|date=2 January 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Conservatorio Nacional de Música y Declamación: Reglamento Interno|url=http://www.bnm.me.gov.ar/giga1/documentos/EL003810.pdf|website=Biblioteca Nacional Mariano Moreno|publisher=Ministry of Culture and Education|accessdate=4 July 2017|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|pages=5–8|language=Spanish|date=1926}}</ref> [[Carlos López Buchardo]] became the first director and the first assistant director was {{ill|Enrique García Velloso|es}}. The conservatory began its operations at the Teatro Colón.<ref name="García" /> Within a few years, in 1930 the Conservatory relocated to the upper floors of the [[Teatro Nacional Cervantes]]. In 1928, renowned Russian prima ballerina, [[Elena Smirnova]] was hired as the first professor of dance of the Conservatory.<ref name="Destaville" >{{cite web|last1=Destaville|first1=Enrique Honorio|title=Elena Alexandrovna Smirnova|url=http://www.ciudaddeladanza.com/bibliodanza/articulos-y-noticias/elena-alexandrovna-smirnova.html|website=Ciudad de la Danza|accessdate=3 July 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161229151030/http://www.ciudaddeladanza.com/bibliodanza/articulos-y-noticias/elena-alexandrovna-smirnova.html|archivedate=29 December 2016|location=Buenos Aires, Argentina|language=Spanish|date=2013|postscript=. Self-published but with citations to source materials.}}</ref>
In 1939, the name was changed to the Conservatorio Nacional de Música y Arte Escénico (National Conservatory of Music and Performing Arts) and it was renamed again upon the death of Buchardo at the end of 1948. The conservatory was renamed to honor its first director, and has since been known as the '''Conservatorio Nacional de "Carlos López Buchardo"'''.<ref name="Clasico" /> In 1950, the Dance Department was split from the organization with the founding of the National School of Dance ({{lang-es|Escuela Nacional de Danzas}}) and then between 1957 and 1958, the Theater Arts Department was separated from the Conservatory to create the National School of Theater ({{lang-es|Escuela Nacional de Teatro}}). Moving several times in the 1940s, by 1982, the Conservatory established its current location (2017) in the Palacio Rocca Avenida Córdoba 2445.<ref name="García" />
==Modern organization== The National Conservatoire was divided in 1989 into the present and independent ''Escuela Nacional de Música'' (basic and first levels) and the '''Conservatorio Nacional Superior de Música''' (middle and high levels).
In 1995, the middle level of the National Conservatorium is assigned to the government of the city of Buenos Aires, which is in 1998 named ''Conservatorio de Música de la Ciudad de Buenos Aires''.
==Alumni== * [[Alberto Ginastera]] – cello, piano, composition and conducting * [[Sylvia Kersenbaum]] – piano * [[Carlos Iván Cítera]] – piano * [[Lilia Sánchez]] – Dalcroze Method * [[Elias Goldzycher]] – piano * [[Ana Lucia Frega]] – Music education * [[Juan Maria Solare]] – piano, composition and conducting * [[Jorge Alejandro Fernández]] – trumpet, singing and choreography * [[Liliana Cangiano]] – piano, composition
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100611055939/http://www.iuna.edu.ar/detalle_contenidos.php?idp=736&id=736&m=722 Instituto Universitario Nacional del Arte (parent university) – Department of Musical and Audio Arts] (Spanish) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051122053253/http://www.iuna.edu.ar/institucional/buchardo.htm Conservatoire's History] (Spanish) *[http://letraymusica.com/conservatorio_nac.htm Conservatoire's Information] (Spanish) *[http://www.clarin.com/diario/especiales/yrigoyen/biografias/buchardo.htm Buchardo Biography] (Spanish) *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060208030841/http://www.buenosaires.gov.ar/areas/cultura/ens_artistica/musica_ciudad.php Conservatorio de Buenos Aires] (Spanish)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Conservatorio Nacional Superior de Musica (Argentina)}} [[Category:Music schools in Argentina]] [[Category:Education in Buenos Aires]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1924]] [[Category:1924 establishments in Argentina]]

revision.comment: /* Popularity */
revision.text:
'''Contemplative education''' is a philosophy of [[higher education]] that integrates introspection and experiential learning into academic study in order to support academic and social engagement, develop self-understanding as well as analytical and critical capacities, and cultivate skills for engaging constructively with others. The inclusion of contemplative and introspective practices in academia addresses an increasingly recognized imbalance in higher education: a lack of support for developing purpose and meaning, or for helping students "learn who they are, search for larger purpose for their lives, and leave college as better human beings".{{ cite news |author=Harry R. Lewis |publisher=PublicAffairs |title=Excellence Without A Soul: How a Great University Forgot Education |date=2006}} == Philosophy == Informed by the many forms of contemplative practice in philosophies and religions the world over, contemplative education invites students to embrace the immediacy of their interior lives as a means for applying their own first-person experiences to what they are learning in their classrooms.{{ cite news |author=Tobin Hart |publisher=Journal of Transformative Education |title=Opening the Contemplative Mind in the Classroom |date=January 2004}} Contemplative practices invite close observation of phenomena (e.g., natural processes, cultural productions, mental and emotional states, biases). These practices provide opportunities to develop attention and focus, increase awareness and understanding, listen and speak across difference, support creative approaches to problem solving, and consider the impacts of our actions on the world at large.{{ cite news |author=Carly Hodes |url=http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/2014/07/contemplative-practices-boost-problem-solving |publisher=Cornell Chronicle |title=Contemplative practices boost creativity in problem-solving |date=July 11, 2014}} Contemplative education is not solely traditional education with, for example, a course in meditation thrown in; it is an approach that offers an entirely new way of understanding what it means to be educated in the modern Western liberal arts tradition. For example, to deepen their academic study, students might engage in [[mindfulness (Buddhism)|mindfulness]] practices in order to cultivate being present-moment awareness, or engage in dialogue and deep listening practices in order to develop interpersonal skills. == Popularity == In the past two decades contemplative practices have become growingly incorporated across curricular settings. It is very difficult to provide exact numbers, however, recent reviews have clearly depicted this as a historical change in which primary, secondary and higher public (not only alternative) educational institutions are becoming far more receptive to these practices. Oren Ergas (2018) A contemplative turn in education: Charting a curricular-pedagogical countermovement. Pedagogy, Culture & Society The philosophy of contemplative education has been present in the United States since at least 1974,{{ cite news |url=http://www.naropa.edu/history.html |publisher=Naropa University |title=History }} but has gained popularity particularly recently as contemplative practices (such as mindfulness and yoga) have sparked the interest of educators at all levels. It has inspired networks of higher-education professionals for the advancement of contemplative education, primarily the Association for Contemplative Mind in Higher Education (ACMHE), which has an international membership of over 750 faculty, administrators, and higher education professionals. The ACMHE was founded in 2008 by the [[Center for Contemplative Mind in Society]] and has convened annual conferences on contemplative education since 2009.{{ cite news |url=http://www.acmhe.org |publisher=The Center for Contemplative Mind in Society |title=The Association for Contemplative Mind in Higher Education }} The formation of the ACMHE was precipitated by the Contemplative Practice Fellowships, a program administered by the Center for Contemplative Mind in Society from 1997 through 2009. Fellowships were awarded to 153 faculty members at 107 colleges and universities for designing and teaching courses which included contemplative methods. This initiative helped to form a community of practice on the use of contemplative methods across higher education disciplines.{{ cite news |author=Barbara A. Craig |url=http://www.contemplativemind.org/admin/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/academic_fellowships_evaluation.pdf |publisher=The Center for Contemplative Mind in Society |title=Contemplative Practice in Higher Education: An Assessment of the Contemplative Practice Fellowship Program, 1997–2009 |date=April 2011 }} While contemplative education aims to integrate contemplative practices and perspectives within any subject of study, the discipline of contemplative studies—the examination of the contemplative experience itself—has also developed. The Contemplative Studies Initiative at [[Brown University]], founded by [[Harold D. Roth|Harold Roth]], Professor of Religious Studies and Director of the Contemplative Studies Initiative, offers a formal concentration in contemplative studies.{{ cite news |publisher=Brown University |title=Contemplative Studies: The Formal Concentration |url=http://www.brown.edu/academics/contemplative-studies/concentrating-contemplative-studies }} Contemplative education also fueled the Bachelor of Fine Arts in Jazz and Contemplative Studies curriculum at The [[University of Michigan]] School of Music, which combines meditation practice and related studies with [[jazz]] and overall musical training.{{ cite news |author=Ed Sarath |publisher=Innovative Higher Education |title=Meditation in Higher Education: The Next Wave? |date=Summer 2003 }} In Colorado, the Rocky Mountain Contemplative Higher Education Network (RMCHEN) launched in September 2006 with an event hosted by [[Naropa University]]. [[Peter Schneider (architecture professor)|Peter Schneider]], a renowned architecture professor at the [[University of Colorado-Boulder]] and [[Barbara Dilley]], a former president of Naropa and an accomplished dancer, choreographer and educator, spoke at the launch of RMCHEN. Dr [[Han F. de Wit]], the author of "[[Contemplative psychology]]", outlined one of the first systematic works suggesting a framework in which a full-fledged contemplative psychology may be developed.{{ cite news |url=http://www.shambhala.org/teachers/acharya/hdewit.php |publisher=SHAMBHALA, Netherlands |title=Contemplative psychology, Han F.de Wit, Duquesne University Press, Pittsburgh,1991 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013184753/http://shambhala.org/teachers/acharya/hdewit.php |archivedate=2012-10-13 |df= }} == In practice at Naropa University == The depth of insight and concentration reached through students’ disciplined engagement with contemplative practices alters the landscape of learning and teaching at [[Naropa University]]{{ cite news |url=https://www.usnews.com |publisher=U.S. News & World Report |title=America's Best Colleges: To learn in the moment |author=Caroline Hsu |year=2005 }} ([[Boulder, Colorado]]) founded by [[Chögyam Trungpa]], Rinpoche in 1974.
"The point is not to abandon scholarship but to ground it, to personalize it and to balance it with the fundamentals of mind training, especially the practice of sitting meditation so that inner development and outer knowledge go hand in hand. . . . A balanced education cultivates abilities beyond the verbal and conceptual to include matters of heart, character, creativity, self-knowledge, concentration, openness and mental flexibility." —Judy Lief, former [[Naropa University]] president
=== Contemplative disciplines === Woven into the curriculum at Naropa, for example, are practices that include sitting [[meditation]], t’ai-chi ch’uan, [[aikido]], [[yoga]], Chinese brushstroke and [[ikebana]]. These are some of the most commonly referred-to contemplative practices, but there are many others, including other traditional arts, ritual practices and activist practices.{{ cite news |url=http://contemplativemind.org/practices/ |publisher=The Center for Contemplative Mind in Society |title=What are contemplative practices? |date=2001–2006 }}{{ cite news |url=http://www.contemplativemind.org/practices/tree.html |publisher=The Center for Contemplative Mind in Society |title=The Tree of Contemplative Practices |date=2001–2006 }} ==References== == External links == {{Portal|Education}} {{Sisterlinks|Education}} * [http://www.acmhe.org/ Association for Contemplative Mind in Higher Education] * [http://www.brown.edu/academics/contemplative-studies/ Brown University Contemplative Studies Initiative] * [https://papers.aarweb.org/content/contemplative-studies-group/ Contemplative Studies Group of the American Academy of Religion] * [http://www.sandiego.edu/cas/contemplativestudies/ Contemplative Studies Website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130206214712/http://www.garrisoninstitute.org/contemplation-and-education/contemplative-education-program-database Garrison Institute's Contemplative Education Program Database] * [http://journal.contemplativeinquiry.org/ Journal of Contemplative Inquiry] * [http://www.mindfuled.org/ Mindfulness in Education Network] * [http://pccs.umich.edu/ University of Michigan Program in Creativity and Consciousness Studies] * [http://www.uvacontemplation.org/ University of Virginia Contemplative Sciences Center] {{DEFAULTSORT:Contemplative Education}} [[Category:Philosophy of education]] [[Category:Academic terminology]] [[Category:Mindfulness movement]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lane Cove, New South Wales]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text: {{Infobox school |name = Currambena School |image = |alt = |caption = |motto = |motto_translation = |city = |state = |country = [[Australia]] |coordinates = {{coord|33|49|15.80|S|151|10|13.01|E|display=title,inline}} |schooltype = |religious_affiliation = |established = 1969 |principal = |viceprincipal = |viceprincipal_label = |asst principal = |assistant_principals = |teaching_staff = |grades = P-6 |enrolment = 93{{cite news|title=Parent power|last=Binger|first=Annette|date=2006-07-02|work=Sunday Age}} |enrollment_as_of = 2006 |campus type = [[Suburban]] |colours = |website = }} '''Currambena School''' is an [[independent school|independent primary]] and [[preschool education|preschool]] in [[Lane Cove]], [[New South Wales]]. ==History== The school was established in 1969, when the then Woodley Preparatory School was purchased by the founders.{{cite web|url=http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/history/|title=History|date=2007|publisher=Currambena School|accessdate=2009-06-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914065424/http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/history/|archivedate=2009-09-14|df=}} It was one of a number of alternative schools that pioneered the application in Australia of the ideas of progressive educationalist [[A. S. Neill]].{{cite book|last=Andresen|first=Lee|author2=David Boud |author3=Ruth Cohen |title=Understanding Adult Education and Training|editor=Foley, G.|publisher=Allen & Unwin|location=Sydney|pages=225–239|chapter=Experienced Based Learning}} The school commenced with 116 students in January 1970: 72 in the preschool and 44 in the primary. The school expanded to include a second adjacent building in 1971. In 2003 the school had 71 students; in 2004 this had grown to 88 students{{cite news|url=http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/smh2004march13teachers-say-tests-will-take-fun-from-learning.pdf|title=Teachers say tests will take fun from learning|last=Dick|first=Tim|date=2004-03-13|work=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=2009-06-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090916040709/http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/wp-content/uploads/2007/12/smh2004march13teachers-say-tests-will-take-fun-from-learning.pdf|archivedate=2009-09-16|df=}} in 2006 the school had 93 students.{{cite news|title=Parent power|last=Binger|first=Annette|date=2006-07-02|work=Sunday Age}} The Commonwealth government uses a measure of socio-economic status of independent schools to help determine their funding; Currambena has scored highly on this scale (meaning its students live in high socio-economic status locations).{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Senate/committee/eet_ctte/estimates/add_0304/dest/e857_04a2.pdf|title=Answer to Question No. E857_04|last=Department of Education, Science and Training|date=February 2004|publisher=Senate Education, Employment and Workplace Relations Committee|accessdate=2009-07-01}} As an alternative school, Currambena experienced external pressures from increasing standardisation of curricula,{{cite web|url=http://alex.edfac.usyd.edu.au/archived%20conferences/ConferencePIC2001/AmyMortimerHonours.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040815205155/http://alex.edfac.usyd.edu.au/archived%20conferences/ConferencePIC2001/AmyMortimerHonours.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2004-08-15|title=Progressive education: The lived experiences of Currambena School 1969-2001|last=Mortimer|first=Amy|date=2001|work=Post Internship Conference 2001|publisher=University of Sydney Faculty of Education|accessdate=2009-06-30}} and from reforms to student assessment. Representatives of the school were prominent in criticising developments in education policy such as the introduction of national standardised tests.{{cite web|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Senate/committee/eet_ctte/completed_inquiries/1999-02/stgrant2000/submissions/sublist.htm|title=Submission to the Inquiry into States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Bill 2000|last=Currambena School Education Committee|date=October 2000|publisher=Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Committee|accessdate=2009-07-01}} ==Organisation and activities== The school is administered by a council comprising six parents and three teachers; it has no school principal.{{cite web|url=http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/school-organisation/|title=School organisation|date=2007|publisher=Currambena School|accessdate=2009-06-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914065517/http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/school-organisation/|archivedate=2009-09-14|df=}} The board is democratic and responsible for curriculum, facilities and employment decisions. The original articles of association stipulated a maximum class size of 25; this was subsequently reduced to 22, with classes split into three age groups.{{cite web|url=http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/class-pages/|title=Class composition|last=Currambena School|date=2007|publisher=Currambena School|accessdate=2009-07-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914062727/http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/class-pages/|archivedate=2009-09-14|df=}} The school emphasises creativity and flexibility in responding to the needs of individual children.{{cite news|title=One-third of pupils go private|last=Denney|first=Margot|date=2001-02-13|work=The Australian}}{{cite news|title=Schools take a star turn|last=Selinger-Morris|first=Samantha|date=2008-04-26|work=Sydney Morning Herald}} ==Alumni== *[[David Heilpern]], author and magistrate{{cite web|url=http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/alumni-information/david-heilpern-1970/|title=David Heilpern - 1970|last=Heilpern|first=David|date=2008|publisher=Currambena School|accessdate=2009-06-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090914100551/http://currambena.nsw.edu.au/general-information/alumni-information/david-heilpern-1970/|archivedate=2009-09-14|df=}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.currambena.nsw.edu.au/ Currambena School, NSW] {{Democratic schools}} {{Portal bar|Australia|Education|Schools}} [[Category:School buildings completed in 1969]] [[Category:Alternative schools]] [[Category:Private primary schools in Sydney]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1969]] [[Category:Lane Cove, New South Wales]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Use British English|date=August 2016}} '''Geraint Johnes''' is Professor of [[Economics]] at Lancaster University Management School.
He was previously Lecturer, Senior Lecturer and Reader in Economics at Lancaster, and has spent periods as a visitor to institutions in the USA ([[Dartmouth College]], [[Lehigh University]]) and Australia ([[Australian National University]]). He has served as honorary visiting professor at Beijing Normal University, and is an associate fellow of SKOPE at [[Oxford University]] and [[Cardiff University]] and of the Robert Owen Centre for Educational Change at the University of Glasgow. From 2014 to 2015, he was Director of [[the Work Foundation]]. He frequently provides media commentary on labour market issues, regularly appearing on television (BBC, Sky News, France 24, DW, RT, ABC etc.) and radio.
He has published widely in the area of the economics of education, including papers in the ''Economic Journal'', ''Oxford Economic Papers'' and ''[[Oxford Bulletin of Economics and Statistics]]''. He has also published in the area of regional economics (with papers in the ''Journal of Regional Science'', ''Annals of Regional Science'' and''Regional Studies'') and [[labour economics]] (in journals including ''Economics Letters'', ''Labour Economics'', ''Public Finance'', the ''Manchester School'').
He is author of a number of economics textbooks He was founding editor of the journal ''Education Economics''. His work has been funded by the DfES, DTI, Office for National Statistics, British Council, OECD, World Bank, and (under several different programmes) the EU.
He won the [http://www.economics.ltsn.ac.uk/ Economics LTSN] award for [http://www.economicsnetwork.ac.uk/awards/ot.htm outstanding teaching in 2003], and Lancaster University's teaching prize in 2006. His teaching and learning innovations include early use of interactive web-based quizzes (from 1997). In 2005, [[the Guardian]] newspaper described him as 'one of the world's pioneering academic [[podcasters]]' (17 August).
==Works== *''Economics for Managers'' (Prentice Hall, 1990) *''The Economics of Education'' (Macmillan, 1993) *''Fundamentals of Labor Economics'' (co-authored with [[Thomas Hyclak]] and Robert Thornton - published by Houghton Mifflin, 2004 *''European Integration: the Human Resource Dimension'' (MCB University Press, 1991) *''Recent Developments in the Economics of Education'' (with [[Elchanan Cohn]], published by Edward Elgar, 1994) *''International Handbook on the Economics of Education'' (with Jill Johnes, published by Edward Elgar, 2004. *''An Exploratory Analysis of the Cost Structure of Higher Education in England'' (DfES, 2005) (jointly authored with Jill Johnes, Emmanuel Thanassoulis, Pamela Lenton and Ali Emrouznejad)
==External links== *[http://www.lums.lancs.ac.uk/economics/profiles/63/ Homepage] *[http://www.lums.lancs.ac.uk Lancaster University Management School]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Johnes, Geraint}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Welsh economists]] [[Category:Academics of Lancaster University]] [[Category:Lehigh University faculty]] [[Category:Dartmouth College faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Education economists]]

page.title: Graduation Pledge of Social and Environmental Responsibility

revision.comment: Rescuing 9 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6beta2)
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=September 2015}} {{cleanup|date=April 2012}}}} The '''Graduation Pledge of Social and Environmental Responsibility''' has been offered since 1987 at [[college]]s and [[University|universities]] throughout the [[United States]] and the world. The Pledge states: ''I pledge to explore and take into account the social and environmental consequences of any job I consider and will try to improve these aspects of any organizations for which I work.'' The purpose of the Pledge is to encourage graduating students to be mindful of the social and environmental impacts of their [[employment]] as they enter the workforce or continue their [[education]]. It is up to students to define for themselves what socially and environmentally responsible means. Over one hundred Universities and colleges as well as some high schools use the pledge to some extent. There are several different types of schools involved, including the following:
* Liberal arts colleges such as [[Manchester University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchester.edu/common/graduation/gpa.htm |title=Graduation Pledge |website=Manchester.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> [[Juniata College]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.juniata.edu/services/provost/commencement/pledge.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209233740/http://www.juniata.edu/services/provost/commencement/pledge.html |archivedate=2011-12-09 |df= }}</ref> [[Muhlenberg College]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.muhlenberg.edu/main/campuslife/sye/GPA.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225221825/http://www.muhlenberg.edu/main/campuslife/sye/GPA.html |archivedate=2011-12-25 |df= }} </ref> and [[Hartwick College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hartwick.edu/about-us/centers-and-institutes/the-pine-lake-institute-for-environmental-and-sustainability-studies/sustainability-at-hartwick/graduation-pledge |title=Pine Lake Institute for Environmental & Sustainability Studies - Hartwick College |website=Hartwick.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> * State universities such as the [[University of Colorado, Boulder]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Pledging for progress |url=http://www.cuindependent.com/2010/03/18/pledging-for-progress/15077 |title=Pledging for progress |website=Cuindependent.com |date=2010-03-18 |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> and the [[University of Florida]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sustainable.ufl.edu/get-involved/student-involvement/green-graduation-pledge |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422202512/http://sustainable.ufl.edu/get-involved/student-involvement/green-graduation-pledge/ |archivedate=2012-04-22 |df= }}</ref> * Private research universities such as the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2007/green-ribbon-tt0606.html |title=Green ribbons signify responsibility pledge | MIT News |website=Web.mit.edu |date=2007-06-06 |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> and [[Stanford University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalethics.org/newsline/2001/06/25/graduation-pledge-gains-ground-again |title=Press Room | Institute for Global Ethics |website=Globalethics.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> * Private graduate schools such as [[Antioch University New England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.antiochne.edu/av/video/SustainabilityPledge2010.cfm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418213901/http://www.antiochne.edu/av/video/SustainabilityPledge2010.cfm |archivedate=2012-04-18 |df= }}</ref> * Schools of faith such as [[Goshen College]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goshen.edu/news/bulletin/sept99/sept99feature.html#thomas |title=Goshen College December Bulletin |website=Goshen.edu |date=1999-05-13 |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> and [[Bethel College (Indiana)|Bethel College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kipcor.org/Students/GraduationPledge.php |title=Graduation Pledge |website=Kipcor.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> * Community Colleges such as [[Estrella Mountain Community College]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.estrellamountain.edu/sustainability/graduationpledge |title=Graduation Pledge | EMCC |website=Estrellamountain.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> [[Mesa Community College]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mesacc.edu/graduation/green-pledge.html |title=Graduation | Mesa Community College |website=Mesacc.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> and [[Broward College]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.broward.edu/environmental_bcc/envrionmental/TheGraduationPledge/page3256.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507135800/http://www.broward.edu/environmental_bcc/envrionmental/TheGraduationPledge/page3256.html |archivedate=2012-05-07 |df= }}</ref> * Professional schools such as the [[Fashion Institute of Technology]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.fitnyc.edu/careerservices/StudentsandAlumni/pledge.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426011857/http://www3.fitnyc.edu/careerservices/StudentsandAlumni/pledge.htm |archivedate=2012-04-26 |df= }} </ref> * Schools outside the U.S. such as [[Trent University]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trentarthur.ca/index.php/columns/1365-the-graduation-green-pledge-we-have-big-choices-to-make |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420204129/http://www.trentarthur.ca/index.php/columns/1365-the-graduation-green-pledge-we-have-big-choices-to-make |archivedate=2012-04-20 |df= }}</ref> and the [[University of Saskatchewan]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://facilities.usask.ca/sustainability/whatissustainability/whatissustainabilitypledge.php |title=University of Saskatchewan Office of Sustainability - Office of Sustainability - University of Saskatchewan |website=Facilities.usask.ca |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> in [[Canada]] and the [[Chinese Culture University]] in [[Taiwan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.pccu.edu.tw/pledge/en1.html |title=Graduation Pledge of PCCU |website=Pccu.edu.tw |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref> Students who voluntarily sign the pledge seek out employment that reflects their values, sometimes turning down jobs with which they do not feel comfortable. Others work to make changes after they are on the job. Some examples include promoting [[recycling]] at their workplace, removing discriminatory language from training materials, working for [[gender equality]] in athletics, and helping to convince employers to reject contracts that would clearly have negative impacts on society or the environment.
The Pledge was first established at [[Humboldt State University]], [[California]], in 1987. Manchester University in [[Indiana]] hosted the effort from 1996 to 2007, at which time [[Bentley University]] near [[Boston]] became the host. The project takes shape in different ways depending on the institution. At some colleges, for example, students sign wallet-sized cards with the Pledge written on them that they can keep as a reminder of the commitment they've made. Some institutions put the Pledge into the formal program for their Commencement ceremonies. At other institutions, pledge signers wear green ribbons or green tassels at Commencement to signify their commitment (some schools use a different color of ribbon). At Bentley University the pledge is a "capstone" of its four-year Civic Leadership Program <ref>{{cite web |url=http://legacy.bentley.edu/alliance/BCLP/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111209232933/http://legacy.bentley.edu/alliance/BCLP/ |archivedate=2011-12-09 |df= }}</ref> and at Humboldt State University, the student government funds a student Pledge coordinator internship. The Pledge serves to promote social and environmental responsibility on three different levels: Students and alumni who are making choices about employment; schools including values and citizenship in their curriculum as opposed to just knowledge and skills; and the workplaces and wider society being concerned about issues beyond just the bottom line. The Graduation Pledge Alliance maintains a web site for campus organizers and those who have signed the Pledge.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.graduationpledge.org |title=Graduation Pledge Alliance | Social and Environmental Responsibility Works |website=Graduationpledge.org |date= |accessdate=2017-03-27}}</ref>
==Further reading== * The Graduation Pledge of Social & Environmental Responsibility: An Effective Tool for Education and Action on Human Rights, by Matt Nicodemus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.graduationpledge.org/newsite/wp-content/uploads/GPA_HRE_essay.docx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111210000803/http://www.graduationpledge.org/newsite/wp-content/uploads/GPA_HRE_essay.docx |archivedate=2011-12-10 |df= }} </ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.graduationpledge.org The Graduation Pledge Alliance website]
[[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Environmental education]]

revision.comment: updated editorial team
revision.text:
{{Infobox journal | title = International Multilingual Research Journal | cover = | editor = [[Jeff MacSwan]] | discipline = [[Linguistics]] | abbreviation = Int. Multiling. Res. J. | publisher = [[Routledge]] | country = | frequency = Triannually | history = 2007–present | openaccess = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.tandfonline.com/action/aboutThisJournal?journalCode=hmrj20 | link1 = http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/hmrj20/current | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://www.tandfonline.com/loi/hmrj20 | link2-name = Online archive | JSTOR = | OCLC = 243599692 | LCCN = | ISSN = 1931-3152 | eISSN = 1931-3160 }} The '''''International Multilingual Research Journal''''' is a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] in [[linguistics]] and [[education]], focusing on the study of [[multilingualism]]. The current editorial team consists of [[Jeff MacSwan]] as Editor-in-Chief and Associate Editors Jeff Bale, Mileidis Gort, and Megan Madigan Peercy. The journal was established in 2007 with [[Terrence G. Wiley]] and [[Alfredo Artiles]] as founding editors.
== Abstracting and indexing == The journal is abstracted and indexed in: [[Linguistics and Language Behavior Abstracts]] and [[ERIC]].
== External links == * {{Official|1=http://www.tandfonline.com/action/aboutThisJournal?journalCode=hmrj20}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox comics creator | image = 10.13.12IvanReisByLuigiNovi1.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Reis at the 2012 [[New York Comic Con]]. | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_place = | nationality = Brazilian | cartoonist = | write = | art = | pencil = y | ink = | edit = | publish = | letter = | color = | alias = | notable works = ''[[Action Comics]]''
''[[Aquaman]]'' vol. 7
''[[Blackest Night]]''
''[[Brightest Day]]''
''[[Ghost (Dark Horse Comics)|Ghost]]''
''[[Green Lantern (comic book)|Green Lantern]]'' vol. 4
''[[Justice League]]''
''[[Rann–Thanagar War]]'' | awards = | website = | subcat = Brazilian }} '''Ivan Reis''' is a [[Brazilians|Brazilian]] [[comics artist]]. He is known for his work on comic books such as [[Dark Horse Comics]]' ''[[Ghost (Dark Horse Comics)|Ghost]]'', [[Marvel Comics]]' ''[[Genis-Vell|Captain Marvel]]'', and [[DC Comics]]' ''[[Action Comics]]'', ''[[Green Lantern (comic book)|Green Lantern]]'' and ''[[Aquaman]]'' series. According to collaborator [[Geoff Johns]], Reis' drawing style resembles a combination of [[Alan Davis]] and [[Neal Adams]].{{cite journal|title = Geoff Johns Conquers the Universe|journal = Comic-Con Magazine|pages = 11|publisher = [[San Diego Comic-Con International]]|date = Winter 2010|url = http://issuu.com/comic-con/docs/ccmag_winter2010}} ==Career== For three years, Reis worked for [[Maurício de Sousa]] in Brazil. He began his international career for [[Dark Horse Comics]] working on ''[[Ghost (Dark Horse Comics)|Ghost]]'', starting with issue #17 and acting as regular artist until the series concluded with issue #36. Other work for Dark Horse included ''[[The Mask]]'', ''Time Cop'', and ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess (comics)|Xena]]''. He later worked for [[Lightning Comics (1990s)|Lightning Comics]].{{gcdb|type=credit|search=Ivan+Reis|title=Ivan Reis}} At [[Vertigo (DC Comics)|Vertigo]], he pencilled an issue of [[Grant Morrison]]'s ''[[The Invisibles]]''.{{cite book|last = Irvine|first = Alex|author-link = Alexander C. Irvine|contribution = The Invisibles|editor-last = Dougall|editor-first = Alastair|title = The Vertigo Encyclopedia|pages = 92–97|publisher = [[Dorling Kindersley]]|location= London, United Kingdom|year = 2008|ISBN = 0-7566-4122-5|oclc = 213309015}} He became better known for ''[[Lady Death]]'' at [[Chaos! Comics|Chaos!]] and [[CrossGen]]. At [[Marvel Comics]], Reis worked on ''The [[Thing (comics)|Thing]] & [[She-Hulk]]: The Long Night'', ''Avengers Icons: [[Vision (Marvel Comics)|Vision]]'', ''[[Genis-Vell|Captain Marvel]]'', ''[[Iron Man]]'', ''The [[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]]'', and ''The [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]''. Since 2004 Reis has worked for [[DC Comics]] on ''[[Action Comics]]'', ''[[Teen Titans]]'', ''[[Rann–Thanagar War]]'', ''[[Superman (comic book)|Superman]]'', and ''[[Infinite Crisis]]''. Reis started pencilling ''[[Green Lantern (comic book)|Green Lantern]]'' vol. 4 with issue #10 (May 2006).{{cite web |url= http://www.newsarama.com/4003-reis-of-the-black-lanterns-ivan-talks-blackest-night.html|title= Reis of the Black Lanterns: Ivan Talks ''Blackest Night''|first= Vaneta|last= Rogers|date= October 9, 2009|publisher= [[Newsarama]]|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131208025757/http://www.newsarama.com/4003-reis-of-the-black-lanterns-ivan-talks-blackest-night.html|archivedate=December 8, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}} Reis left ''Green Lantern'' after issue #38 (March 2009) to draw the ''[[Blackest Night]]'' limited series (June 2009 – May 2010){{cite book|last=Cowsill|first= Alan|last2=Dolan|first2=Hannah, ed.|chapter= 2000s|title = DC Comics Year By Year A Visual Chronicle|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|year=2010|location= London, United Kingdom|isbn= 978-0-7566-6742-9 |page= 339|quote = Artist Ivan Reis handled the vast array of characters with amazing skill, bringing out the emotional core of Johns' brilliant script.}} and its follow-up limited series ''[[Brightest Day]]'' (July 2010 - June 2011).{{cite web |url= http://www.newsarama.com/2272-ivan-reis-preparing-for-blackest-night.html|title= Ivan Reis: Preparing for ''Blackest Night''|first= Vaneta|last= Rogers|date= February 19, 2009|publisher= Newsarama|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131208030059/http://www.newsarama.com/2272-ivan-reis-preparing-for-blackest-night.html|archivedate=December 8, 2013|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}}Cowsill "2000s" in Dolan, p. 341: "Cowritten by Geoff Johns and Peter J. Tomasi, and illustrated by Ivan Reis, Patrick Gleason, Ardian Syaf, Scott Clark, and Joe Prado, ''Brightest Day'' was the start of the next chapter in the history of the DC Universe." Reis was the regular penciller of writer [[Geoff Johns]]' run on ''[[Aquaman]]'' vol. 7, which premiered in September 2011. Reis drew it for the first 13 issues before moving to ''[[Justice League]]'' where he replaced [[Jim Lee]].{{cite web |url= http://www.bleedingcool.com/2012/08/14/ivan-reis-to-move-from-aquaman-to-justice-league/|title= Ivan Reis To Move From ''Aquaman'' To ''Justice League''?|first= Rich|last= Johnston|authorlink = Rich Johnston|date= August 14, 2012|publisher= Bleeding Cool|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120817092957/http://www.bleedingcool.com/2012/08/14/ivan-reis-to-move-from-aquaman-to-justice-league/|archivedate=August 17, 2012|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web |url= http://www.bleedingcool.com/2012/08/20/geoff-johns-to-leave-aquaman-with-ivan-reis/|title= Geoff Johns To Leave ''Aquaman'' With Ivan Reis|first= Rich|last= Johnston|date= August 20, 2012|publisher= Bleeding Cool|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121024073721/http://www.bleedingcool.com/2012/08/20/geoff-johns-to-leave-aquaman-with-ivan-reis|archivedate= October 24, 2012|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}} Johns and Reis introduced the [[Crime Syndicate of America]] into the New 52 continuity in ''Justice League'' #23 (Oct. 2013).{{cite book|last= Manning|first= Matthew K.|last2=Dougall|first2=Alastair, ed.|chapter= 2010s|title= Batman: A Visual History|publisher= [[Dorling Kindersley]]|year= 2014|location= London, United Kingdom|page= 338|isbn= 978-1465424563|quote= Writer Geoff Johns and artist Ivan Reis unveiled the true masterminds between the recent infighting among the various Justice Leagues.}} Reis drew the first issue of Grant Morrison's ''[[The Multiversity]]'' in 2014.{{cite web |url= http://www.newsarama.com/21941-vivisecting-multiversity-with-ivan-reis-joe-prado.html|title= Vivisecting ''Multiversity'' With Ivan Reis & Joe Prado|first= Vaneta|last= Rogers|date= August 21, 2014|publisher= Newsarama|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141019172009/http://www.newsarama.com/21941-vivisecting-multiversity-with-ivan-reis-joe-prado.html|archivedate= October 19, 2014|deadurl= no|df=mdy-all}} Reis drew the first issue of [[Brian Michael Bendis]]' ''The Man of Steel'' limited series{{cite web|url= http://www.multiversitycomics.com/interviews/ivan-reis-joe-prado-man-of-steel/|title= Ivan Reis and Joe Prado, Art Team Behind ''The Man of Steel'' #1, Talk About What Makes Superman Special|first= Brian|last= Salvatore|date= May 30, 2018|publisher= Multiversity Comics|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180804041653/http://www.multiversitycomics.com/interviews/ivan-reis-joe-prado-man-of-steel/|archivedate= August 4, 2018|deadurl= no|df= mdy-all|quote= This story has extra weight behind it, as it is Brian Michael Bendis’s first big story at DC, and a sort of reset for the Superman status quo.}} and collaborated with Bendis on the relaunched ''[[Superman (comic book)|Superman]]'' ongoing series in 2018.{{cite web|url= https://www.newsarama.com/40731-brian-bendis-showcases-big-ivan-reis-art-in-superman-launch.html|title= Bendis' ''Superman'' Going to 'Farthest Reaches of Everything DC has to Offer'|first= Vaneta|last= Rogers|date= July 9, 2018|publisher= Newsarama|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20180710003802/https://www.newsarama.com/40731-brian-bendis-showcases-big-ivan-reis-art-in-superman-launch.html|archivedate= July 10, 2018|deadurl= no|df= mdy-all|quote= With artist Ivan Reis on ''Superman'', Bendis will be writing a story he calls 'very big, with big stories and big villains and big goings-on in the DC Universe, the kind of things only Superman can handle.'}} ==Bibliography== Interior art (except where noted) includes: ===Chaos! Comics=== *''[[Lady Death]]: **''Alive'' #2 (with [[Brian Pulido]], 2001) **''Dark Alliance'' #1–3 (with writer [[John Ostrander]], 2002) **''Jade'' #1 (with writer [[Brian Augustyn]], 2002) **''Judgement War'' #3 (with writers Brian Pulido and [[Len Kaminski]], 2000) **''Last Rites'' #4 (with writer John Ostrander, 2002) **''The Rapture'' #2–3 (with writers Brian Pulido and Len Kaminski, 1999) ===CrossGen=== *''Lady Death: A Medieval Tale'' #1–6 (with writer Brian Pulido, 2003) *''[[Crux (comics)|Crux]]'' #21 (2003) ===Dark Horse Comics=== *''[[Ghost (Dark Horse Comics)|Ghost]]'' #17–25, 28–31, 33–36 (1996–98) *''[[Xena: Warrior Princess (comics)|Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' #3 (with [[Mike Deodato]]) (1999) ===DC Comics=== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *''[[Action Comics]]'' (Lana Lang) #812; (Superman) #813–819, 822–825 (with writer [[Chuck Austen]], 2004–05) *''[[Aquaman]]'', vol. 7, #1–13, #0 (with writer [[Geoff Johns]], 2011–12) *''[[The Authority (comics)|The Authority]]'' vol. 3 #9 (backup story, with writer [[Christos Gage]], 2009) *''[[Batman]]'', vol. 3, #6 (2016) *''[[Blackest Night]]'', miniseries, #0–8 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2009–10) *''Blackest Night: Tales of the Corps'', miniseries, #3 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2009) *''[[Brightest Day]]'' #1–14, 16–24 (with writers Geoff Johns and [[Peter Tomasi]], among other artists, 2010–11) *''[[Countdown to Infinite Crisis]]'' #1 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2005) *''[[Cyborg (comics)|Cyborg]]'' #1–6 (with writer David F. Walker, 2015–16) *''DC Comics – [[The New 52]] [[Free Comic Book Day|FCBD]] Special Edition'' #1 (among other artists, 2012) *''DC Comics: The New 52 Zero Omnibus'' (cover art, 2012) *''[[DC Universe]]'' #0 (among other artists) (2008) *''DC Universe: Rebirth'' #1 (among other artists; & variant cover artist first printing, 2016) *''DCU Holiday Special'' #1 (among other artists) (2009) *''[[52 (comics)|52]]'' #22 (Green Lantern backup story, with writer [[Mark Waid]], 2006); #51 (Justice League backup story, with writer Mark Waid, 2007) *''[[Green Lantern (comic book)|Green Lantern]]'', vol. 4, #10–17, 21–25, 29–38, ''Super Spectacular'' (with writer Geoff Johns, 2006–11) *''[[Infinite Crisis]]'', miniseries, #4–7 (among other artists) (2005–06) *''Infinite Crisis Special: Rann–Thanagar War'' #1 (with writer [[Dave Gibbons]], 2006) *''[[The Invisibles]]'', vol. 2, #18 (with writer [[Grant Morrison]], 2000) *''[[Justice League]]'', vol. 2, #8, 12, 15–17, 19, 22–24, 26–28, 30, 35 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2012–14) *''Justice League of America'', vol. 4, #25 (with writer [[Dwayne McDuffie]], among other artists, 2008) *''Justice League of America'', vol. 5, #1, 4, 12–14 (2017) *''Justice League of America: The Atom - Rebirth'' #1 (cover art, 2017) *''Justice League of America: Vixen - Rebirth'' #1 (cover art, 2017) *''Justice League of America: The Ray - Rebirth'' #1 (cover art, 2017) *''Justice League of America: Killer Frost- Rebirth'' #1 (cover art, 2017) *''[[Kamandi]] Challenge'' #5 (with writer [[Bill Willingham]], 2017) *''The Man of Steel'', miniseries, #1 (with writer [[Brian Michael Bendis]], 2018) *''[[The Multiversity]]'' #1–2 (with writer Grant Morrison, 2014–15) *''[[Rann–Thanagar War]]'', vol. 2, miniseries, #1–6, ''Special'' #1 (with writer Dave Gibbons, 2005–06) *''[[Superman vol. 2|Superman]]'', vol. 2, #223 (with writer [[Mark Verheiden]], 2006) *''Superman'', vol. 4, #14 (2017) *''Superman'', vol. 5, #1–4, 100-Page Giant Special (2018) *''[[Superman/Batman]]: Secret Files 2003'' (with writer Geoff Johns) *''[[Teen Titans]]/[[Outsiders (comics)|Outsiders]] Secret Files 2003'' (with writer Geoff Johns) *''Teen Titans/[[Legion of Super-Heroes|Legion]] Special'' #1 (with writers Geoff Johns and Mark Waid, 2004) *''Untold Tales of Blackest Night'' #1 (among other artists) (2010) *''[[Wildcats (comics)|WildCATS]]'', vol. 2, #9 (backup story, with writer Christos Cage, 2009) {{div col end}} ===Marvel Comics=== *''The Supernaturals'' (with writer [[Marc Andreyko]]), five-issue limited series, [[Marvel Comics]], 1998 *''[[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]]'' vol. 3 #52, 64 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2003), ''Annual 2001'' (with writer [[Kurt Busiek]], 2001) *''Avengers Icons: [[Vision (Marvel Comics)|Vision]]'', miniseries, #1–4 (with writer Geoff Johns, 2002) *''[[Genis-Vell|Captain Marvel]]'' vol. 3 #4, 9–12 (with writer [[Peter David]], 2003) *''[[Defenders (comics)|Defenders]]'' vol. 2 #12 (backup story, with writers Kurt Busiek and [[Jo Duffy]], 2002) *''[[Quicksilver (comics)|Quicksilver]]'' #7, 9 (1998) *''Supernaturals'', miniseries, #1–4 (1998) *''[[Thing (comics)|The Thing]]/[[She-Hulk]]: The Long Night'' #1 (with writer [[Todd DeZago]], 2002) ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *{{comicbookdb|type=creator|id=55|title=Ivan Reis}} *[http://www.mikesamazingworld.com/mikes/features/creator.php?creatorid=2517 Ivan Reis] at Mike's Amazing World of Comics *[http://www.maelmill-insi.de/UHBMCC/namr9.htm#N1338 Ivan Reis] at the revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2012}}
'''jam2jam''' is a family of audiovisual software for collaborative performance. The systems use [[generative systems|generative]] algorithms for audio and visual material whose parameters are controlled by users with either a graphical user interface or external hardware controllers. jam2jam software applications can connect over local networks or the internet allowing real-time collaboration. This type of functionality is referred to as Network Jamming and is the topic of ongoing research.<ref>Network Jamming research is documented here: http://acid.net.au/index0b83.html?option=com_content&task=view&id=64&Itemid=134</ref>
The jam2jam software has been primarily employed to enable access to collaborative audiovisual performances, and is used in [[education]] and [[community arts]] settings.<ref>Educational and community arts uses of jam2jam are documented here: http://explodingart.com/jam2jam/jam2jam/Research/Research.html</ref> The software has also found application in assisting people with [[disabilities]] to participate in playful arts activities.
The Network Jamming research that surrounds the use of jam2jam is built on a [[constructivist epistemology]] and encourages learning about audio and visual media through interactive performances and making by video recording the performances. The jam2jam software facilitates this philosophical approach by enabling collaboration through network connections and allows performances to be recorded for review and sharing. There are a number of academic publications describing this research.<ref>Academic articles on Network Jamming research using jam2jam: http://explodingart.com/jam2jam/jam2jam/Research/Entries/2007/8/11_Publications.html</ref>
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * jam2jam.com [http://jam2jam.com/]
[[Category:Computer music software]] [[Category:Educational software]]
