revision.text:
An '''online college fair''', or '''virtual college fair''', is a relatively recent phenomenon that consists of a collection of colleges and universities that communicate and provide information online during a specific timeframe. An online college fair operates according to several of the usual conventions of a “brick and mortar” college fair: there are event halls, schools have booths that prospective students and/or parents can visit to exchange information, and there are speaker sessions by various admissions and education experts. However, the entire fair is contained online, and therefore an online college fair can also have many of the characteristics of a [[virtual world]]. One of the main benefits of an online college fair is that travel cost is eliminated for both school representatives and students.
==History== The first such online college fair was organized by the [[National Association for College Admission Counseling]] (NACAC) and held on October 9, 2001. Approximately 200 institutions participated; the number of participating students is unknown. This first online college fair was widely considered a failure as the number of students trying to log on overloaded the system.<ref>[http://chronicle.com/free/2002/08/2002080901t.htm The Chronicle for Higher Education]</ref> NACAC, which planned on conducting online college fairs on a regular basis, discontinued the program after the initial event.
Additional online college fair providers have come and gone. Gradschools.com hosted an online college fair in conjunction with a live fair. This event also ran into technical difficulties; namely firewall problems and recruiters that were not prepared to use the online chat features.<ref>[https://www.questia.com/library/p435015/matrix-the-magazine-for-leaders-in-higher-education/ Matrix: The Magazine for Leaders in Education] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914234115/https://www.questia.com/library/p435015/matrix-the-magazine-for-leaders-in-higher-education/ |date=September 14, 2015 }}</ref> In November 2002, the Big Apple College Fair also had an online college fair in conjunction with a live fair.<ref>[http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-2222136/Big-Apple-College-Fair-for.html PR Newswire]</ref>
In October 2007, [[BusinessWeek]], which produces annual rankings of United States business school [[MBA]] programs, held a MBA Expo 2007 with the tagline “Find the B-School that fits you best.” A total of 8 US and international business schools attended.
[[CollegeWeekLive]] entered the market in November 13, 2007<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/webguide/internetlife/2007-11-12-virtual-college-fair_N.htm USA Today]</ref> and continues as the leading provider of online college fairs today. CollegeWeekLive grew 67% in 2012.<ref>[http://www.universitybusiness.com/news/virtual-college-fair-provider-collegeweeklive-grows-67-2012-fueled-partnerships-new-products University Business]</ref>
CappexConnect launched in 2013. Part of the Cappex family of websites, CappexConnect is a website dedicated to hosting online college fairs and online open houses.<ref>[http://www.cappexconnect.com CappexConnect]</ref>
==Current Online College Fairs== On March 23 & 24, 2011 [[CollegeWeekLive]] conducted the largest online college fair up until that date, with over 60,000 event attendees.<ref>http://www.collegeweeklive.com</ref> The fair allowed attendees to interact with college admissions officials and college students from 250 schools via instant messaging and video chat. The fair also included 15 keynote speakers addressing several topics including financial aid, diversity, college essays. etc. Speakers included Lynn O'Shaughnessy, college blogger at [[CBS MoneyWatch]] and [[Harlan Cohen]], Author of The Naked Roommate.
CappexConnect hosts online college fairs multiple times throughout the year, providing students the opportunity to connect with hundreds of colleges and universities and thousands of students from across the country. Students can chat directly with college and university representatives as well as fellow prospective students. Students can watch live presentations from admissions experts and financial aid specialists on topics such as choosing a college, financial aid, and choosing a major. Attendees also have the opportunity to enter to win a college scholarship. On September 10, 2013 and October 9, 2013, CappexConnect hosted a fall fair series that included over 15,000 student attendees visiting online booths from over 90 colleges and universities.<ref>[http://blog.cappex.com/blog/college-life/cappexconnect-online-college-fair-what-is-it/ Cappex College Insider]</ref>
College Fairs Online is a new website devoted to high quality virtual college fairs. They hold college fairs by state and connect many colleges with prospective students.<ref>http://www.collegefairsonline.com</ref>
VASA Virtual Education Expo conducts virtual education fairs which bring together universities and potential students.<ref>http://www.virtualeducationexpo.com</ref>
With more people utilizing the web for college search information as well as with the spread of broadband internet access, online college fairs are becoming a major resource for college application information. Colleges are continuously using online chat as a way to connect with prospective students.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-admissions-chat-20130102,0,81673.story Los Angeles Times]</ref>
College fairs offer students that might not otherwise have easy access to college information or the ability to visit colleges. Univision Media, in collaboration with CollegeWeekLive, held a virtual college fair<ref>[http://vidayfamilia.univision.com/es-el-momento/educate/noticias/article/2012-09-20/semana-educacion-es-el-momento-univision-college-fair-week-live Vida y Familia, Univision]</ref> with several presentations in Spanish.
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:University and college admissions]] [[Category:Tertiary educational websites]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in the United States]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
[[File:Stop The Killing KC Headquarters entrance, October 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Entrance of Stop The Killing KC headquarters building, October 2012.]]'''Stop The Killing KC''' is a community improvement organization in [[Kansas City, Missouri]] patterned after ''"stop the violence/stop the killing"'' movements in other large American cities, urged since 1985 by Minister [[Louis Farrakhan]] of the [[History of the Nation of Islam|Nation of Islam]] movement,<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1989-10-06/local/me-628_1_los-angeles-street-gang George Farrakhan to Speak to 900 Gang Leaders to 'Stop the Killing'] [[Los Angeles Times]], October 6, 1986</ref> and drawing on lessons learned in past decades by many other community improvement organizations such as [[urban development]] programs in various U.S. Cities and evangelical or social outreach programs of various churches, religions or groups.
==History== The Kansas City organization became unofficially established with a ''Declaration of Unity'' signed by [[Nation of Islam]] Student Minister Vincent Muhammad, Pastor Tony R. Caldwell of [[Community United KC]], Kenneth "Sasteh Meter" Mosley of [http://emwot.ws EMWOT](East Meets West of Troost), and more than three dozen other community improvement activists on September 17, 2011.
After several meetings and discussions in ensuing weeks, Pastor Caldwell, Captain Muhammad, Sasteh Meter Mosley, and other community leaders met at the [[Bruce R. Watkins Cultural Heritage Center]] on Feb. 11, 2012<ref>[http://www.kshb.com/dpp/news/local_news/community-leaders-hold-forum-to-stop-violence-in-kansas-city Community leaders hold forum to stop violence in Kansas City] [[KSHB-TV]], February 11, 2012</ref> and called for all interested persons to meet the following Saturday, February 18, and create a working organization. On March 3, 2012, an organizational meeting elected officers, including a President and Vice-President, but in mid-May policy disagreements among officers resulted in that organizational structure being abandoned for a seven-member Advisory Council. Stop The Killing KC was formally incorporated on March 14, 2012, with a dedicatory "open house" April 7, 2012.<ref>[http://www.kshb.com/dpp/news/local_news/organization-opens-safe-house-to-help-tackle-violence Organization opens safe house to help tackle violence] [[KSHB-TV]], April 7, 2012</ref> In flyers publicizing the event, Stop the Killing KC lists more than seventy "partners" as being supportive in a "Stop The Killing KC [[Coalition]]":
::''A Newly Adopted Cleanup, Aldi's, Amen Par Ankh, Amen Ankh Urban Farm, American Indian Council, Aim for Peace, Black United Front, C&A Contracting, C.A.C., CASA Veterans Institute, Inc.., The Chess Club, Church of Christ, City of Kansas City, New Community United KC, COOL Wayne, C.U.M.F.H. Property, Durham & Williams, EMWOT(East Meets West of Troost), Eternal Life Church & Family Life Center, Fade N Aces, First Time Correctional Services of KC, FOCUSED, Green Griot, Habitat for Humanity, Happy Foods Grocery, Heart of America Ministries, Help ALL, Inc., Hip Hop Community, Infidelity Annihilators, Inc., Kansas City Fire Dept., Kansas City Parks & Recreation, KC Helping Hands, KCPD, KD Construction, Key Coalition, King Richard, L.I.N.K., Littlejohn for Sheriff, Man Up Program, Mazuma Credit Union, Morning Star Baptist Church, My Brother's Keeper, NAU, Occupy KC, PeaceKeepers, Penny Mill, Pinnacle Career Institute, Price Chopper, R.E. Bishop Construction, Inc., Roxann Grocia, Samuel Rogers, Save A Child, Save Tomorrow's Outstanding People, Second Chance Program, Servants for Jesus, Simply Designed, Swope Health Services, S.T.O.P., Teola Powell, Troost Fest, Tycor Community Development Corp., TSD Sound, The Church of Jesus Christ, The Nation of Islam Mosque 30, PLAN, The Salvation Army, Truly Concerned Youth & Adults, Underground Railroad, Urban Life Ministry, Urban Work Force, Vaterott College, Voices of the People, Whatsoever Community Center, Women in Motion, Wonder Bread, Women's Coalition, Youth Wagon Productions.''
==Activities== [[File:Neighborhood basketball tournament stk-kansas city.jpg|thumb|left|Participants at the second "3 on 3" Basketball tournament hosted by Stop The Killing KC Coalition on July 29, 2012]]Activities the group has encouraged or sponsored include vigils and funerals for deceased victims of violence, crime investigation, distributing flyers at busy intersections, canvassing crime-hit neighborhoods, voter registration drives, daily and nightly classes, Study Groups, like- Literacy for youth and adults, Health and Wellness awareness and food program,feeding youth and children through the summer and after school, urban agriculture, vocational green career opportunities and seminars, participation in events such as Kansas City's [[Troost Festival]] on April 28, 2012; the annual [[Convoy of Hope]] festival on June 16, 2012 and so forth. On the afternoon of July 1, 2012 the STK-KC held a "3 on 3" basketball tournament,<ref>[http://www.kshb.com/dpp/news/crime/community-members-hope-to-reduce-violence-with-basketball-tournament Community members hope to reduce violence with basketball tournament] [[KSHB-TV]], July 1, 2012</ref> Missouri State Representative [http://ballotpedia.org/wiki/index.php/Brandon_Ellington Brandon Ellington] participated, and Kansas City's Chief of Police Darryl Forte visited, as well as other community leaders and basketball players and fans from around the city. On July 29, 2012, STK-KC hosted a second 3 on 3 tournament "Shoot Baskets- Not Bullets!", and scheduled two basketball events for every month throughout the summer of 2012.
==Incidents== On May 14, 2012 a Kansas City woman named Andrea Shields was murdered and her body then set on fire.<ref>[http://image.issuu.com/120525164057-30734a12318343e3b3107c8ddcf475d8/jpg/page_1.jpg Police Identify Woman Brutally Murdered And Set On Fire]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} [[The Call (Kansas City)]], May 25–31, 2012 edition</ref> Stop the Killing KC and other anti-violence organizations held vigils for and coordinated funeral arrangements for Shields. The funeral was scheduled for 2 p.m. Saturday May 26, 2012. Shortly after 4 a.m. that morning a drive-by shooter fired eight bullets toward Stop the Killing KC's headquarters building, seven rounds lodging in a vehicle parked in front of the building, one round chipping siding near the building's "Stop the Killing KC" sign.<ref>[http://fox4kc.com/2012/05/26/crime-fighting-organization-receives-threats Crime Fighting Organization Receives Threats][[WDAF-TV]], May 26, 2012</ref> Allegedly, someone phoned Kansas City's "Tips Hotline" the day before, and demanded that Stop the Killing KC '"back off from the Andrea Shields investigation"'. Because Stop The Killing KC is a "Crime Prevention" and pro-[[Civil Rights]] organization, Federal Law Enforcement agencies are investigating the incident along with Kansas City police.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== :1. revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Notability|Academics|date=October 2012}} {{BLP sources|date=October 2012}} }}
{{Infobox scientist | name = Susie W. Håkansson | image = | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth-date and age | July 15, 1940}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | fields = [[Mathematics education]] | workplaces = [[University of California, Los Angeles]] | alma_mater = [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] | doctoral_advisor = Noreen Webb | doctoral_students = | known_for = | awards = }}
'''Susie Wong Håkansson''' (born July 15, 1940) is known for her work in [[mathematics education]], teacher preparation and [[professional development]]. Since 1999, she has been Executive Director of the [[California Mathematics Project]].
== Education == After completing her primary schooling at [[Los Angeles High School]], went on to receiving her bachelor's and master's degrees in mathematics, and a teaching credential from [[University of California, Santa Barbara]], and her doctorate in education from [[University of California, Los Angeles]]. Her graduate advisor was Dr. Noreen Webb and her thesis was titled ''The effects of daily problem solving on problem-solving performance, attitudes towards mathematics, and mathematics achievement''.<ref>Hakansson, Susan Wong. 1990. ''The effects of daily problem solving on problem-solving performance, attitudes towards mathematics, and mathematics achievement.'' Thesis (Ph. D.) – University of California, Los Angeles, 1990.</ref>
== Life == Susie (Susan) Wong Håkansson is a native Southern Californian born and raised in Los Angeles. Her parents are first generation Chinese immigrants who owned a small business in the [[Larchmont]] area.
After gaining her master's degree, Håkansson taught for several years at [[Huntington Park High School]] in [[Los Angeles Unified School District]] and was involved in several projects to improve the teaching and learning of mathematics. She served as a head track and field coach and official specializing in pole vault and had the opportunity of working at the [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Olympics]] at Los Angeles. In 1984, she joined [[Center X]] in the [[UCLA Graduate School of Education and Information Studies]] and served as the site director of the UCLA Mathematics Project. She took on the position as the statewide Executive Director for the California Mathematics Project in 1999.
== Awards ==
* Robert Sorgenfrey Distinguished Teaching Award, UCLA, 2009 * Walter Denham Memorial Award (Advocacy for Mathematics Education), California Mathematics Council, 2009<ref>{{cite web|title=CAMTE Advisory Board Member Receives Walter Denham Award|url=http://www.camte.org/hakansson.html|accessdate=5 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Walter Denham Memorial Award|url=http://cmc-math.org/members/denham.html|accessdate=5 October 2012}}</ref>
== External links == * [https://www.facebook.com/SusieWHakansson Official Facebook fanpage]
== References ==

revision.text:
{{COI|date=August 2010}} '''Induction''' is the support and guidance provided to novice [[teacher]]s and school administrators in the early stages of their careers. Induction encompasses orientation to the workplace, socialization, [[mentoring]], and guidance through beginning teacher practice.
Comprehensive, high-quality induction consists of several key elements: * a multi-year program * rigorous mentor selection and training * subject-area pairing of mentors and beginning educators * sufficient time for mentors to meet with and observe new educators * [[formative assessment]] that assists beginning educators to advance along a continuum of professional growth.
The [[New Teacher Center]] induction model is nationally recognized in the United States for its promotion of new educator development and its impact on teacher retention and student learning.
== References == * Alliance for Excellent Education, "Tapping The Potential: Retaining and Developing High-Quality New Teachers", 2005. [https://web.archive.org/web/20040802224119/http://www.all4ed.org/publications/TappingThePotential/index.html] * [[American Association of State Colleges and Universities]], "Teacher Induction Programs: Trends and Opportunities," 2006. [http://www.aascu.org/policy_matters/pdf/v3n10.pdf] * [[Ellen Moir|Moir, Ellen]], "Launching The Next Generation of Teachers Through Quality Induction," National Commission on Teaching and America's Future, 2003. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070114165547/http://nctaf.org/documents/Moir2.doc] * National Commission on Teaching and America's Future, "Induction into Learning Communities," 2005. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070711025024/http://www.nctaf.org/documents/NCTAF_Induction_Paper_2005.pdf] * New Teacher Center at UC Santa Cruz, "Does New Teacher Support Affect Student Achievement? - Some Early Research Findings," 2006. [http://www.newteachercenter.org/pdfs/NTCResearchBrief.06-01.pdf] * New Teacher Center at UC Santa Cruz, "Mentoring New Teachers to Increase Retention - A Look at the Research," 2005. [http://www.newteachercenter.org/pdfs/NTCResearchBrief.05-01.pdf] * Smith, Thomas M., "How Do State-Level Induction and Standards-Based Reform Policies Affect Induction Experiences and Turnover among New Teachers?," American Journal of Education, volume 113 (2007), pages 273–309. * Smith, Thomas M. and Ingersoll, Richard M. "What Are the Effects of Induction and Mentoring on Beginning Teacher Turnover?” American Educational Research Journal 41 (Fall 2004). [http://www.gse.upenn.edu/faculty_research/Effects-of-Induction-and-Mentoring-RMI-Fall-2004.doc]{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} * Portner, H. (Ed.). (2005). Teacher mentoring and induction: The state of the art and beyond. Thousand Oaks, CA: Corwin.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Teacher Induction}} [[Category:Education reform]] [[Category:Teacher training]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Teaching for Change | image =Teaching for Change logo.jpg | image_size =210px | type = 501(c)3 | founded_date = 1989 December | tax_id = 52-1616482 | registration_id = | founder = | location = Washington, DC | coordinates = {{Coord|38.917813|-77.031777|format=dms}} | origins = | key_people = Kate Tindle, Board Co-Chair | area_served = [[United States]] | product = | mission = Teaching for Change provides teachers and parents with the tools to create schools where students learn to read, write and change the world. | focus = educational | method = parent organizing, professional development, and publications | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = 21 | num_members = | subsid = | opponents = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = "Building social justice, starting in the classroom." | former name = Network of Educators on Central America | homepage = http://www.teachingforchange.org | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
'''Teaching for Change''' is a non-profit organization founded in 1989 and based in Washington D.C. with the motto of "building social justice, starting in the classroom." This organization uses publications, professional development, and parent organizing programs to accomplish this goal.
==Programming==
Teaching for Change coordinates a variety of programs that aim to encourage teachers, students, and parents to build a more equitable, multicultural society through education.
===Tellin' Stories=== The Tellin' Stories program is a process for building parent engagement in schools. This program uses a bottom-up approach, encouraging parents to define what their roles will be.<ref>[https://www.rethinkingschools.org/articles/tellin-stories-finding-common-ground "Tellin Stories, Finding Common Ground" By David Levine, Rethinking Schools, 2009]</ref> The training plan has four stages: * Community Building: families meet each other and learn about their schools; * Information Gathering: parents analyze the school climate, the facilities, and the quality of teaching and learning at their school; * Identifying and Prioritizing Concerns: parents investigate concerns with schools (using Right Question Project methodology); and * Taking Action: parents determine the action required to achieve desired results and work collectively to promote those actions.<ref>National Family, School, and Community Engagement Working Group, [http://www.hfrp.org/publications-resources/browse-our-publications/taking-leadership-innovating-change-profiles-in-family-school-and-community-engagement Taking Leadership/Innovating Change: Profiles in Family School and Community Engagement] Harvard Family Research Project, March 2010.</ref>
===Teaching for Change Bookstore=== Teaching for Change founded and operated an independent, non-profit bookstore <ref>[http://www.shelf-awareness.com/issue.html?issue=1320#m10680 "Teaching for Change at Busboys and Poets" in ''Shelf Awareness'', November 2, 2010]</ref> located inside [[Busboys and Poets]] 14th and V Streets location for ten years.<ref name="Washingtonian">Todd Kliman, [http://www.washingtonian.com/articles/restaurants/1785.html Rainbow Room: The Busboys and Poets Controversy], ''Washingtonian'', December 1, 2005.</ref> The bookstore hosted author events and provided vetted selections of books focusing on progressive politics, multicultural lessons for pre K-12, and [[people's history]]. Teaching for Change helped bring noted authors to host readings, discussions and book signings, including [[Alice Walker]], [[Howard Zinn]], [[Cornel West]], [[Ronald Takaki]], [[Michelle Alexander]], [[Melissa Harris-Perry]], [[John Sayles]], [[Nikki Giovanni]], [[Robert Parris Moses]], [[Juan Gonzalez (journalist)|Juan Gonzalez]], [[Ralph Nader]], [[Taylor Branch]], [[Dave Zirin]], [[Naomi Klein]], [[Tariq Ali]], [[Clarence Lusane]], [[Marita Golden]], [[Charles E. Cobb Jr.]], [[Bernie Sanders]], [[Edwidge Danticat]], [[Judy Richardson]], and [[Junot Diaz]]. Teaching for Change closed its bookstore in April 2015 and shared its recommendations for books online.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/act-four/wp/2015/03/18/teaching-for-change-moves-online-amid-challenges-for-diversity-in-books/ "Teaching for Change Moves Online Amid Challenges for Diversity in Books" by Stacia Brown in ''The Washington Post'', March 18, 2015]</ref>
===Zinn Education Project=== Teaching for Change co-founded the Zinn Education Project with Rethinking Schools in 2008 to provide teachers with free resources to help teach a [[people's history]] including free downloadable lesson plans as a companion to [[Howard Zinn]]'s ''[[A People's History of the United States]]'' and other classroom resources for educators around the country.<ref>[http://www.yesmagazine.org/EdConnectionNews/may10/default.html "''Yes!Magazine'' recommends the Zinn Education Project", May, 2010]</ref>
===Civil Rights Teaching=== Beginning in 2006, Teaching for Change worked with the [[McComb School District]] and the [[Mississippi Department of Education]] for ten years to incorporate lessons on the [[civil rights movement]] and [[Labor history of the United States|labor history]] in the curriculum. The stated intention was to help schools "end a decades-old culture of silence" on difficult historical events in the region.<ref>Carmen K. Sisson, [http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/2009/1008/p25s02-usgn.html Mississippi mandates civil rights classes in schools] ''Christian Science Monitor'', October 8, 2009</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.good.is/articles/these-mississippi-teens-should-school-the-supreme-court-on-the-voting-rights-act|title=These Mississippi Teens Should School the Supreme Court on the Voting Rights Act|date=2013-03-12|work=GOOD Magazine|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en}}</ref> McComb Legacies, an after-school and summer enrichment program, grew out of the partnership between Teaching for Change and the McComb School District. As part of McComb Legacies, high school students work as historians to uncover the history of the voting rights struggle in McComb and [[Mississippi]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hechingerreport.org/lessons-mississippis-violent-past-become-optional/|title=Have lessons about Mississippi’s violent past become optional? - The Hechinger Report|date=2014-06-22|work=The Hechinger Report|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-US}}</ref> In the spring of 2013, two McComb student projects made it to the national level of the [[National History Day]] competition. ''The Voting Rights Struggle'', a documentary film created by McComb students, tells the story of the first [[SNCC]] voter registration drive, which was located in McComb.<ref>Titus Ledbetter III, [https://archive.is/20130629093411/http://www.afro.com/sections/news/washington/story.htm?storyid=78857 Mississippi Students Take Award-Winning Voting Rights Documentary to Nation's Capital] AFRO, June 19, 2013.</ref> The film can now be seen at the [[African American Civil War Museum]] in Washington, DC.<ref>Deborah Barfield Berry, [http://www.clarionledger.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2013306130035&nclick_check=1|Students showcase civil rights work] ''Jackson Clarion-Ledger'', June 12, 2013.</ref>
==History==
In the 1980s, with a growing Central American population and U.S. involvement in the region, 11 committees of educators and community leaders formed across the country to assess how to address the needs of Central American students and increase public awareness about U.S. foreign policy in [[Central America]]. These committees convened in Los Angeles to form a national organization, the Network of Educator’s Committees on Central America (NECCA) that became incorporated in December 1989<ref>[http://www.teachingforchange.org/about/history/25-years History] Teaching for Change website, 2017</ref>
Through the early 90s they produced teaching resources on [[Nicaragua]] and [[El Salvador]] and hosted teacher workshops around the country based on the book ''Rethinking Columbus''.<ref>Rethinking Columbus, http://www.rethinkingschools.org/ProdDetails.asp?ID=094296120X Rethinking Schools.</ref> In 1993, NECCA won the Humanities award from the DC Humanities Council and in 1994 they launched a mail order catalog for progressive teaching resources.
As the organization expanded its focus, NECCA changed its name to Teaching for Change. Through the 1990s, Teaching for Change organized seminars for educators on social justice education topics and published their own teaching guide, ''Beyond Heroes and Holidays: A Practical Guide to K-12 Anti-Racist, Multicultural Education and Staff Development''.
In 1999, Teaching for Change hosted a seminar for educators in the DC area focusing on "putting the movement back into Civil Rights" history teaching at [[Howard University]]. That seminar led to the production of a teaching guide with the same name, in collaboration with the Poverty and Race Resource Action Council (PRRAC).
''Putting the Movement Back into Civil Rights Teaching'' won the Philip C. Chinn book of the year award <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nameorg.org/philip_chinn_book_award.php|title=Philip Chinn Book Award - National Association for Multicultural Education|website=nameorg.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref> and Teaching for Change won the National Association for Multicultural Education Organization of the Year in 2004.
In 2005, Teaching for Change was invited by former board member and entrepreneur [[Andy Shallal]] to open a bookstore in [[Busboys and Poets]].
In 2008, in partnership with Rethinking Schools, they launched the Zinn Education Project to provide middle and high school teachers with free access to lessons for [[Howard Zinn]]’s ''[[A People's History of the United States]]'' and other people's history resources.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/bostonia/summer17/bringing-zinn-to-class/|title=Bringing Zinn to Class|last=|first=|date=|website=Bostonia|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2014, Teaching for Change was attacked by [[Rush Limbaugh]] who said of the organization, "it’s racist, it’s bigoted." <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://origin-www.rushlimbaugh.com/daily/2014/06/16/rush_revere_books_dissed_on_c_span2/|title=Rush Revere Books Dissed on C-SPAN2|work=The Rush Limbaugh Show|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bookweb.org/news/teaching-change-supporters-react-limbaugh-slam|title=Teaching for Change, Supporters React to Limbaugh Slam|date=2014-06-19|work=American Booksellers Association|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/city-desk/blog/13068736/rush-limbaugh-attacks-the-bookstore-at-busboys-and-poets|title=Rush Limbaugh Attacks the Bookstore at Busboys and Poets|work=Washington City Paper|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en}}</ref>
Teaching for Change launched the Teach the Beat initiative <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tmottgogo.com/teach-the-beat-go-go-goes-to-school-artists-and-scholars-in-the-classroom-sept-29-2015-video/|title=Teach the Beat: Go-Go Goes to School: Artists and Scholars in the Classroom|last=|first=|date=2015-10-15|work=TMOTT GO GO Magazine|access-date=2017-08-21|language=}}</ref> to bring [[go-go]] artists to D.C. classrooms and was among the national recipients of the [[W. K. Kellogg Foundation]] Family Engagement Awards <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wkkf.org/news-and-media/article/2014/04/wkkf-recipients-of-13-million-investment-empower-parents-as-leaders-and-key-decision-makers|title=W.K. Kellogg Foundation announces recipients of $13.7 million investment to empower parents as leaders and key decision makers in education|last=|first=|date=2014-04-17|work=W.K. Kellogg Foundation|access-date=2017-08-21|language=en-US}}</ref> in 2014.
== References == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.teachingforchange.org/ Teaching for Change] website * [http://www.zinnedproject.org/ Zinn Education Project] website * [http://www.teachingcentralamerica.org/ Teaching Central America] website * [http://www.civilrightsteaching.org/ Civil Rights Teaching] website * [http://www.socialjusticebooks.org/ Social Justice Books] website *[https://www.dcareaeducators4socialjustice.org/ D.C. Area Educators for Social Justice] website

revision.text:
{{Infobox journal | title = The Leadership Quarterly | image = <!-- or |cover= --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | former_name = <!-- or |former_names= --> | abbreviation = Leadersh. Q. | bluebook = <!-- For law journals only --> | mathscinet = <!-- For the MathSciNet abbreviation IF different from ISO 4 abbreviation--> | nlm = <!-- For the NLM abbreviation IF different from ISO 4 abbreviation--> | subject = [[Leadership]] | peer-reviewed = | language = English | editor = [[John Antonakis]] | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | country = | history = 1990–present | frequency = Bimonthly | openaccess = | license = | impact = 3.307 | impact-year = 2017 | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = 1048-9843 | eISSN = 1873-3409 | CODEN = LEQUEN | JSTOR = | LCCN = 91650980 | OCLC = 780556109 | website = https://www.journals.elsevier.com/the-leadership-quarterly/ | link1 = https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/journal/10489843 | link1-name = Online access | link2 = https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-leadership-quarterly/issues | link2-name = Online archive }} '''''The Leadership Quarterly''''' is a bimonthly [[peer-review]]ed multidisciplinary [[social science]] [[academic journal|journal]]. It is dedicated to the scientific study of [[leadership]]. The journal has a broad focus and publishers papers from various fields of [[Social sciences|social science]] ([[psychology]], [[economics]], [[political science]]) as well as of [[Biological Science|biological science]] (e.g., [[evolutionary psychology]]). The journal also publishes methodological advances.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-leadership-quarterly|title=The Leadership Quarterly {{!}} ScienceDirect.com|website=www.sciencedirect.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-19}}</ref>
The journal was established in 1990 and is published by [[Elsevier]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/the-leadership-quarterly|title=The Leadership Quarterly {{!}} ScienceDirect.com|website=www.sciencedirect.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-19}}</ref>. The current [[editor-in-chief]] is [[John Antonakis]] ([[University of Lausanne]]). According to the ''[[Journal Citation Reports]]'', the journal has a 2017 [[impact factor]] of 3.307, which puts it in the first quartile in management and applied psychology.<ref name="WoS">{{cite book |year=2018 |chapter=The Leadership Quarterly |title=2017 [[Journal Citation Reports]] |publisher=[[Clarivate Analytics]] |edition=Science |series=[[Web of Science]]}}</ref> It has a CiteScore of 4.41<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://journalinsights.elsevier.com/journals/1048-9843/citescore|title=Elsevier Journal Metrics Visualization. Helping Authors. Visualizing Key Metrics. Delivering Journal Insights.|website=journalinsights.elsevier.com|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref> According to various journal quality lists, ''The Leadership Quarterly'' is highly ranked.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://harzing.com/resources/journal-quality-list|title=Journal Quality List|work=Harzing.com|access-date=2018-07-17|language=en}}</ref> Its acceptance rate is below 10%.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Antonakis|first=John|date=February 2017|title=Editorial: The future of The Leadership Quarterly|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.leaqua.2017.01.005|journal=The Leadership Quarterly|volume=28|issue=1|pages=1–4|doi=10.1016/j.leaqua.2017.01.005|issn=1048-9843}}</ref>
Former editors include<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S104898431830300X/pdfft?md5=1da12530b7322587d1015109d500afee&pid=1-s2.0-S104898431830300X-main.pdf|title=The Leadership Quarterly, Masthead|last=|first=|date=|website=www.sciencedirect.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref>:
* Leanne E. Atwater, University of Houston, USA, 2010-2016 * Michael D. Mumford, University of Oklahoma, USA, 2005-2010 * James G. Hunt, Texas Tech University, USA, 1999-2004 * Francis Yammarino, State University of New York at Binghamton, USA, 1992-1998 * Henry L. Tosi, Jr., University of Florida, 1991-1992 * Robert J. House, University of Pennsylvania, 1991-1992 * Bernard M. Bass, State University of New York at Binghamton, 1990
== Awards == The journal was recently distinguished by one of its recent articles,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liang|first=Lindie H.|last2=Brown|first2=Douglas J.|last3=Lian|first3=Huiwen|last4=Hanig|first4=Samuel|last5=Ferris|first5=D. Lance|last6=Keeping|first6=Lisa M.|date=August 2018|title=Righting a wrong: Retaliation on a voodoo doll symbolizing an abusive supervisor restores justice|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.leaqua.2018.01.004|journal=The Leadership Quarterly|volume=29|issue=4|pages=443–456|doi=10.1016/j.leaqua.2018.01.004|issn=1048-9843|via=}}</ref> which won the 2018 [[Ig Nobel Prize|Ig Nobel]] prize in Economics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.improbable.com/ig/winners/#ig2018|title=Improbable Research|website=www.improbable.com|access-date=2018-09-15}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.journals.elsevier.com/the-leadership-quarterly/}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Leadership Quarterly, The}} {{Social-science-journal-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}}
{{Infobox comic strip | fgcolor = | bgcolor = | title = The World Museum Dioramas | image = File:The World Museum 16 MAY 1937.jpg | alt = The World Museum Diorama of 16 May, 1937: Treasure Hunters of the Sea | caption = The World Museum Diorama of 16 May, 1937: ''Treasure Hunters of the Sea'' | author = [[Holling C. Holling|Holling Clancy Holling]] | current = | illustrator = [[Holling C. Holling|Holling Clancy Holling]] | website = | status = Discontinued | first = May 09, 1937 | last = January 30, 1938 | altnames = | syndicate = | publisher = | genre = | rating = | preceded by = | followed by = }}
'''The World Museum''' was a [[full page|full-page]] [[Sunday strip|illustrated feature]] in some American [[Sunday comics|Sunday newspapers]], starting in June 1937 until January 1938. Devised and drawn by [[Holling C. Holling|Holling Clancy Holling]] (1900–1973), it was also known as '''The World Museum Dioramas'''.<ref>Advertisement - Evening Star - May 08, 1937, Page C-10</ref>
The Evening Star in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] and the Baltimore American both published the dioramas.<ref name="Coronation">The Coronation of King George the Sixth and Queen Elizabeth - Evening Star - May 09, 1937 - Page 3</ref><ref>Advertisement - The Midland Journal - May 21, 1937 - page 4</ref> Publication in the Evening Star abruptly stops in February 1938 in spite of the next diorama, ''Log Cabin Days'' (scheduled for February 6, 1938) being announced in the January 30, 1938 issue along with ''Roman Gladiators''. No announcement of the cancellation seems to have been done. <ref name="AmericanDesert">American Desert - Evening Star [volume], January 30, 1938, Page 3, Image 103</ref>
==Format== Each diorama was published in the Sunday edition and occupied a full page in color. It featured all the parts to be cut out by the reader with detailed instructions to cut out the pictures and assemble them into a [[diorama]] using wrapping paper to stiffen the strucutre. Each new diorama had a paragraph explaining the diorama itself from a historical or geographical point of view. Subject included historical events, natural wonders or international ethnographic scenes.<ref name="Coronation"/>
==List of Dioramas== These are the dioramas published from May 1937 to January 1938 the [[Washington, D.C.]] Evening Star. The names are the titles as published in the newspapers. Names in [ ] are clarification comments for titles that are not clear.
May 1937: * The Coronation of King George the Sixth and Queen Elizabeth <ref name="Coronation"/> * Treasure Hunters of the Sea <ref>Treasure Hunters of the Sea - Evening Star [volume], May 16, 1937, Page 4, Image 120</ref> * Castles in Spain <ref>Castles in Spain - Evening Star [volume], May 23, 1937, Page 3, Image 111</ref> * Dragons that Walked on the Water [Viking Ship] <ref>Dragons that Walked on the Water - Evening Star [volume], May 30, 1937, Page 3, Image 83</ref>
June 1937: * The Creeping Wall [Glacier] <ref>The Creeping Wall - Evening Star [volume], June 06, 1937, Page 5, Image 109</ref> * The Indian Buffalo Hunters <ref>The Indian Buffalo Hunters - Evening Star [volume], June 13, 1937, Page 7, Image 129</ref> * The Working Elephant <ref>The Working Elephant - Evening Star [volume], June 20, 1937, Page 5, Image 109</ref> * Making a Motion Picture <ref>Making a Motion Picture - Evening Star [volume], June 27, 1937, Page 4, Image 104</ref>
July 1937: * When the Liberty Bell Rang <ref>When the Liberty Bell Rang - Evening Star [volume], July 04, 1937, Page 3, Image 73</ref> * When Dinosaurs Roamed the Earth <ref>When Dinosaurs Roamed the Earth - Evening Star [volume], July 11, 1937, Page 5, Image 95</ref> * Life in a Dutch Village <ref>Life in a Dutch Village - Evening Star [volume], July 18, 1937, Page 4, Image 96</ref> * Tibetan Devil Dancers <ref>Tibetan Devil Dancers - Evening Star [volume], July 25, 1937, Page 4, Image 98</ref>
August 1937: * China Clipper [A Small Plane] <ref>China Clipper - Evening Star [volume], August 01, 1937, Page 4, Image 100</ref> * Fulton's First Steamboat <ref>Fulton's First Steamboat - Evening Star [volume], August 15, 1937, Page 3, Image 99</ref> * Whale Hunting <ref>Whale Hunting - Evening Star [volume], August 22, 1937, Page 4, Image 94</ref> * African Waterhole <ref>African Waterhole - Evening Star [volume], August 29, 1937, Page 4, Image 98</ref>
September 1937: * An Indian School <ref>An Indian School - Evening Star [volume], September 05, 1937, Page 3, Image 75</ref> * Perry's Victory [War of 1812] <ref>Perry's Victory - Evening Star [volume], September 12, 1937, Page 3, Image 125</ref> * Polish Village Festival <ref>Polish Village Festival - Evening Star [volume], September 19, 1937, Page 4, Image 112</ref> * Balboa at the Pacific <ref>Balboa at the Pacific - Evening Star [volume], September 26, 1937, Page 5, Image 103</ref>
October 1937: * The Ohio Mound Builders [Native Americans] <ref>The Ohio Mound Builders - Evening Star [volume], October 03, 1937, Page 5, Image 119</ref> * Discovery of America [Christopher Columbus] <ref>Discovery of America - Evening Star [volume], October 10, 1937, Page 3, Image 113</ref> * Dancing Scotch Villagers <ref>Dancing Scotch Villagers - Evening Star [volume], October 17, 1937, Page 3, Image 119</ref> * Interior of a Coal Mine <ref>Interior of a Coal Mine - Evening Star [volume], October 24, 1937, Page 7, Image 127</ref> * Indian False Faces [Native American Masks]<ref>Indian False Faces - Evening Star [volume], October 31, 1937, Page 4, Image 126</ref>
November 1937: * The Pool of Death [A prehistoric tar pool in California] <ref>The Pool of Death - Evening Star [volume], November 07, 1937, Page 5, Image 113</ref> * A Lacrosse Game <ref>A Lacrosse Game - Evening Star [volume], November 14, 1937, Page 7, Image 137</ref> * First Thanksgiving <ref>First Thanksgiving - Evening Star [volume], November 21, 1937, Page 3, Image 113</ref> * The Grand Canyon <ref>The Grand Canyon - Evening Star [volume], November 28, 1937, Page 3, Image 111</ref>
December 1937: * Eskimo Life <ref>Eskimo Life - Evening Star [volume], December 05, 1937, Page 6, Image 132</ref> * Lion Spearing <ref>Lion Spearing - Evening Star [volume] (Washington, D.C.), December 12, 1937, Page 2, Image 128</ref> * Mexican Christmas <ref>Mexican Christmas - Evening Star [volume], December 19, 1937, Page 3, Image 121</ref> * The Three Wise Men <ref>The Three Wise Men - Evening Star [volume], December 26, 1937, Page PAGE 3, Image 91</ref>
January 1938: * Chinese New Year <ref>Chinese New Year - Evening Star [volume], January 02, 1938, Page 3, Image 107</ref> * First Bullfights <ref>First Bullfights - Evening Star [volume], January 09, 1938, Page 3, Image 99</ref> * Siamese Temple <ref>Siamese Temple - Evening Star [volume], January 16, 1938, Page 3, Image 103</ref> * Roman Gladiators <ref>Roman Gladiators - Evening Star [volume], January 23, 1938, Page 4, Image 96</ref> * American Desert <ref name="AmericanDesert"/>
February 1938: * Log Cabin Days (Announced but unpublished) <ref name="AmericanDesert"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://hollingcholling.blogspot.be/ Informative and exhaustive blog dedicated to Hollings' work.] * [http://nwda-db.wsulibs.wsu.edu/findaid/ark:/80444/xv45499 Guide to the Holling Clancy Holling papers at the University of Oregon] * [http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/tf6k4007bt Guide to the Holling Clancy Holling papers at the University of California Los Angeles]

Robot - Speedily moving category UNESCO Goodwill ambassadors to [[:Category:UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} '''UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors''' are celebrity advocates of [[UNESCO]] (not diplomatic [[ambassador]]s) who use their talent or fame to spread the UNESCO ideals, especially attracting media attention. Other specialized categories of advocate include [[UNESCO Artist for Peace]], [[UNESCO Champion for Sport]] and [[UNESCO Special Envoy]]. ==Current list== The following is a list of UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors along with the projects and activities they support.UNESCO.org: [http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=4053&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html ''UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors:''] {| class="wikitable" ! Name !! Country !! Ambassador since !! Projects and activities they supportUNESCO.org: [http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=23998&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html ''Projects and activities supported by UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors''] !! Shaker]] || {{flagcountry|Oman}} || 1989–2011 || [http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/about-us/who-we-are/goodwill-ambassadors/former-honorary-and-goodwill-ambassadors/sheikh-ghassan-i-shaker/][http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=8328&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html] |} ==See also== * [[List of UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors]] * [[UNFPA Goodwill Ambassador]] * [[UNHCR Goodwill Ambassador]] * [[UNIDO Goodwill Ambassador]] * [[UNIFEM Goodwill Ambassador]] * [[WHO Goodwill Ambassador]] *[[FAO Goodwill Ambassador]]s ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * UNESCO.org: [http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001825/182559e.pdf Brochure of UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors] * [[BBC News]]: [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/683690.stm The UN's goodwill hunters] [[Category:UNESCO]] [[Category:Goodwill ambassador programmes]] [[Category:UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors| ]]

{{About|the driving game|the Danny Phantom tie-in game|Danny Phantom: Urban Jungle}} {{Infobox video game | italic title = | title = Urban Jungle | image = Urban Jungle (video game) - Main menu (izbornik).jpg | alt = | caption = ''Urban Jungle'' main menu | developer = Urban Development | publisher = Autoklub Rijeka
Talented Programmers Association of Rijeka (DIR) | series = | engine = | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] | released = {{Video game release|WW|6 December 2005}} | genre = [[Educational video game|Educational]] [[driving game]] | modes = [[Single-player]] }} '''''Urban Jungle''''' is a [[freeware]] educational [[driving game]]. The game features a virtual version of the city centre of the Croatian city of [[Rijeka]]. The player drives a car through the city, performing missions for money while taking care not to break traffic rules; a later update also added a driving school simulation. ''Urban Jungle'' is the first educational driving game made in Croatia. The development started in June 2002; a total of 40 people worked on the project, which was financed through grants and [[in-game advertising]]. The game was previewed in November 2005 and published by Autoklub Rijeka and Talented Programmers Association of Rijeka (DIR) the following month. The game saw use as a tool to promote safe driving by the Croatian authorities. In 2013, a sequel was announced, but it was reported to be still in development by the end of 2016. ==Gameplay== [[File:Urban Jungle (video game) - Inside the car (adamiceva iz auta).jpg|thumb|left|Gameplay screenshot. The player is driving through Rijeka city centre.]] The player drives a car through Rijeka, performing time-limited missions.{{cite web|title=Upute - Urban Jungle 1.00|url=http://urbanjungle.dir.hr/upute.php|website=Urban Jungle|publisher=DIR|accessdate=15 July 2017|language=hr|date=3 December 2005}} After each completed mission, they are rewarded with money and penalised for breaking traffic laws. If enough in-game money is accrued, it is possible to buy better cars.{{cite web|title=Igra Urban Jungle - prva cestovna simulacija u Hrvatskoj|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/igra-urban-jungle--prva-cestovna-simulacija-u-hrvatskoj/293535.aspx|website=[[Index.hr]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=8 December 2005}} Money can also be spent on fuel, repairs of damage resulting from crashes, and traffic infractions. The player must be careful not to hit pedestrians, which are, in order to avoid graphic violence, represented by [[crash test dummy|crash test dummies]].{{cite web|last1=Šehović|first1=J.|title=Predstavljen projekt "Urban Jungle" - cestovne prometne simulacije|url=http://www.rijeka.hr/default.aspx?art=4011&sec=340|publisher=City of Rijeka|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=24 November 2005}}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} If the player accumulates too much damage on their car or too many [[point system (driving)|penalty points]], or hits a police officer, the game ends. A [[driver's education]] mode was added to the game in a 2007 update, entitled ''Urban Jungle: Autoškola v1.1'' (''autoškola'' means "driving school" in [[Croatian language|Croatian]]). The player has to complete driving exams at a test track before being allowed to undertake driving missions. The update also featured more detailed graphics, a renewed car pool and more complicated missions.{{cite web|last1=Radešić|first1=Damir|title=Urban Jungle: Auto škola|url=http://www.bug.hr/master/vijesti/urban-jungle-auto-skola/84130.aspx|website=[[BUG (magazine)|BUG Online]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=19 December 2007}} The developers also added weather, the ability to go sightseeing in-game as a pedestrian, the ability to receive insurance reimbursement for damage caused by non-player cars, and the ability to purchase a new vehicle through a bank loan.{{cite web|last1=Orlić|first1=Gordan|title=Urban Jungle: Auto škola zakrpa v1.1|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/gameland/igre/urban-jungle-auto-skola-zakrpa-v1.1/3653439/|website=[[Jutarnji list]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|location=Zagreb|language=hr|date=18 December 2007}} ==Development== The development of ''Urban Jungle'' started in June 2002. The game was financed through [[in-game advertising]] by local and foreign companies and nonprofit organisations such as [[UNICEF]]. It also received funds from the government of the City of Rijeka.{{cite journal|title=Plan raspodjele sredstava za programe javnih potreba u tehničkoj kulturi Grada Rijeke za 2009. godinu|journal=Službene novine Primorsko-goranske županije|date=19 December 2008|volume=XVI|issue=51|url=http://www.sn.pgz.hr/default.asp?Link=odluke&id=15772|accessdate=27 December 2016|publisher=City of Rijeka|language=hr}} Around 40 people worked on the project. The game programmers built their own [[3D engine]], Urban3D. Parts of the game, including 3D models and some of the textures, were designed on [[Macintosh|Mac]] computers. There were plans to port the game to Mac OS X, which were abandoned with Apple's transition to [[x86]] architecture.{{cite web|last1=Kapsalis|first1=Roberta|title=Interview - Davor Pasarić s prijateljskog Jabučnjaka|url=http://www.mackorisnik.com/2008/11/22/interview-davor-pasaric-s-prijateljskog-jabucnjaka/|website=MacKorisnik.com|accessdate=13 July 2017|language=hr|date=22 November 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006012237/http://www.mackorisnik.com/2008/11/22/interview-davor-pasaric-s-prijateljskog-jabucnjaka/|archivedate=6 October 2015|df=}} ==Release and legacy== The game was previewed at the International Fair of New Technologies on 24 November 2005, and again in 2007.{{cite web|last1=Balen|first1=Iva|title=Sajam novih tehnologija ugošćuje 111 izlagača|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/arhiva/sajam-novih-tehnologija-ugoscuje-111-izlagaca/3769650/|website=[[Jutarnji list]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=23 April 2007}} It was released on 6 December 2005,{{cite web|last1=Petrak|first1=Andrej|title=Urban Jungle 2: Daroviti riječki informatičari izrađuju nasljednika legendarne prometne simulacije|url=http://www.novilist.hr/Znanost-i-tehnologija/Znanost/Urban-Jungle-2-Daroviti-rijecki-informaticari-izraduju-nasljednika-legendarne-prometne-simulacije|website=[[Novi list]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=3 July 2013}} and made available for free download online, and distributed in computer magazines. It was published by Autoklub Rijeka and Talented Programmers Association of Rijeka (DIR, ''{{lang|hr|Udruga darovitih informatičara Rijeke}}''). The game was hailed as the first Croatian driving simulation game where players had to abide by traffic rules. In 2006 Autoklub Rijeka held a competition in playing ''Urban Jungle'' for high school students, awarding the winner with free driving lessons.{{cite web|last1=Đečević|first1=J.|title=Natjecanje srednjoškolaca u vožnji kroz virtualnu Rijeku|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/arhiva/natjecanje-srednjoskolaca-u-voznji-kroz-virtualnu-rijeku/3395753/|website=[[Jutarnji list]]|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=hr|date=20 March 2006}} In 2016, Rijeka police used the game to promote road transport safety.{{cite web|author1=|title=(FOTO) ODLIČNO! Riječka policija i Udruga darovitih informatičara videoigru Urban Jungle prenamijenili u besplatni virtualni tečaj autoškole|url=http://rijecanin.rtl.hr/foto-odlicno-rijecka-policija-i-udruga-darovitih-informaticara-videoigru-urban-jungle-prenamijenili-u-besplatni-virtualni-tecaj-autoskole/|website=RiječanIN|publisher=[[RTL Group]]|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=hr|date=11 November 2016}} ==Sequel== In 2013, a sequel was announced, entitled ''Urban Jungle 2''. It is to be distributed on both Windows and [[OS X|Mac]], and possibly feature a virtual version of [[Zagreb]], the capital of Croatia.{{cite web|last1=Pasarić|first1=Davor|title=Urban Jungle 2 dolazi i na Mac!|url=http://www.jabucnjak.hr/novosti/softver/urban-jungle-2-dolazi-i-na-mac.html|website=Jabučnjak|accessdate=12 July 2017|language=hr-hr|date=28 June 2013}} ''Urban Jungle''{{'}}s original engine, Urban3D, was to be replaced by [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] in the next installment. ''Urban Jungle 2'' would also be a [[massively multiplayer online game]]. As of November 2016, ''Urban Jungle 2'' was still in development. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|Urban Jungle (video game)}} * [http://uj.dir.hr Urban Jungle homepage] * [http://www.urbanjungle2.com/ Urban Jungle 2 project homepage] [[Category:Driving simulators]] [[Category:Advergames]] [[Category:Video games developed in Croatia]] [[Category:Educational video games]] [[Category:Video games set in Croatia]] [[Category:2005 video games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]]

revision.comment: Robot: Editing intentional link to disambiguation page in hatnote per [[WP:INTDABLINK]] [[User:RussBot#About the hatnote task|(explanation)]]
revision.text:
{{Other uses|Waiting list (disambiguation){{!}}Waiting list}} [[File:Lafayette College admissions department waitlist letter.jpg|thumb|right|400px|Colleges use waitlists to hedge their bets, uncertain about how many accepted students will say yes, and to draw applicants from the waitlist when vacancies open. In addition, waitlists allow colleges to target acceptance letters to students likely to attend to maintain the college's selectivity ranking and [[Yield (college admissions)|yield]].]] '''Wait list''', in [[university and college admissions]], is a term used in the United States and other countries to describe a situation in which a college or university has not formally accepted a particular student for admission, but at the same time may offer admission in the next few months if spaces become available.<ref name=twsL14>{{cite news |author= Carolyn Butler |title= Follow 7 Strategies to Get Into College: To stand out in the admissions game, prepare early and use common sense |publisher= ''US News'' |date= September 13, 2011 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/articles/2011/09/13/follow-7-strategies-to-get-into-college?PageNr=2 |accessdate= 2011-12-12 }}</ref> It is a contingent offer only, and may mean an offer of admission in the future, or it may not, depending on circumstances. It has been described as a type of college admissions "purgatory",<ref name=twsZe19/> or being held in "the higher-ed equivalent of limbo".<ref name=twsZe21>{{cite news |author= Lynn O'Shaughnessy |title= Getting Off a College Wait List: 5 Things to Do Now |publisher= ''CBS News'' |date= April 9, 2010 |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505145_162-37241846/getting-off-a-college-wait-list-5-things-to-do-now/ |accessdate= 2011-12-31 }}</ref> The percent of applicants offered admission, who decide to accept, is known as the ''admissions yield'',<ref name=twsZe23>{{cite news |author= JACQUES STEINBERG |title= The Early Line on Admission Yields (and Wait-List Offers) |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= May 12, 2010 |url= http://thechoice.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/05/12/yield-3/ |accessdate= 2011-12-31 }}</ref> and this proportion varies somewhat from year to year, and reflects economic conditions as well as interest in a given university.
Colleges mailing out wait list offers generally advise students to reserve a spot at a college they have been accepted to by sending in a deposit, usually several hundred dollars<ref>Note: the deposit varies with the college</ref> to guarantee that the student will have a place at any college in the fall. Later, if a student is accepted by a college from a wait list, and if he or she chooses to accept the wait list offer, it usually entails sacrificing that earlier deposit. In the [[United States]], for students applying by regular admission, the month of April is a time when much activity happens; colleges email offers of acceptance and rejection, and students select a college by sending a deposit. In May, after receiving deposits, colleges know how many spots will be open, and will usually begin to offer admission to students on their wait lists as positions become open. Students can be offered admission from the wait list during May and June and throughout the summer.
According to several reports, colleges and universities use wait lists to try to hedge their guesses about how many students will ultimately decide to accept their offers of admission in any given academic year, with the idea being to build "a reservoir of qualified students to draw from to replace successful applicants who choose to go elsewhere."<ref name=twsZe22/> If fewer students say yes, then colleges will often go to their wait lists to try to find replacements.<ref name=twsL14/> In 2010, according to one source, roughly 10% of college applicants were put on a wait list.<ref name=twsZe19>{{cite news |author= Zach Miners |title= You've Been Put on the Wait List for College. Now What? |publisher= ''US News'' |date= April 9, 2010 |url= https://www.usnews.com/education/best-colleges/right-school/timeline/articles/2010/04/09/youve-been-put-on-the-wait-list-for-college-now-what |accessdate= 2011-12-31 }}</ref>
Wait lists tend to be used by elite and selective universities as well as second-tier liberal arts colleges who are uncertain about how many students will show up in the fall; for example, [[Stanford University|Stanford]] and [[Yale University|Yale]] put 1,000 students on their wait lists and [[Duke University|Duke]] put 3,000 on their wait list, according to one report in 2010.<ref name=twsZe21/> [[Amherst College|Amherst]] takes 35 students from the 1,000 students on its wait list.<ref name=twsZe22/> And as a general rule, selective colleges and universities will usually have some form of wait list. Of the students on a wait list at a highly selective school, a fraction may be offered admission before classes begin in late August or September. One report said the fraction of wait-listed students who were eventually offered admission––as an average of all students wait listed in a given year––was 30%,<ref name=twsZe21/> but this is an overall average, and the fraction of wait-listed applicants to prestigious universities, who are eventually admitted, is much less. Students who are wait-listed can take steps to improve their chances of admission from a wait list by writing letters of interest and by sending second-semester senior grades.<ref name=twsZe22>{{cite news |author= Tracy Jan |title= Students hope to beat college waiting list |publisher= ''The Boston Globe'' |date= April 18, 2009 |url= http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/04/18/students_hope_to_beat_college_waiting_list/ |accessdate= 2011-12-31 }}</ref> Wait listed students are ranked by the admissions department in terms of overall desirability, based on the college's estimation of admissions criteria, and more highly ranked waitlisted students are offered admission first when spots open; this ranking is not revealed to the public.
==Yields and wait list acceptances==
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- |+Yields and wait list offers 2009-2010 |- !College !Yield (2009) !Yield (2010) !Wait list acceptances (2009) !Wait list acceptances (2010) !Notes |- |align="left"|Harvard |align="right"|75% |align="right"|76% |align="right"| |align="right"|70 |align="left"|avg 65 & 75 est |- |align="left"|Dartmouth |align="right"|48% |align="right"|55% |align="right"|95 |align="right"|0 |align="left"| |- |align="left"|Stanford |align="right"|71% |align="right"|72% |align="right"|126 |align="right"|26 |align="left"|<ref name=twsZe24>{{cite news |author= The Daily News Staff |title= Stanford yield rate may be highest ever |publisher= ''The Stanford Daily'' |date= May 7, 2010 |url= http://www.stanforddaily.com/2010/05/07/stanford-yield-rate-may-be-highest-ever/ |accessdate= 2011-12-31 }}</ref> |- |align="left"|U. Pennsylvania |align="right"|63% |align="right"|63% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"| |- |align="left"|SUNY New Paltz |align="right"|20% |align="right"|21% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"| |- |align="left"|Cornell |align="right"|49% |align="right"|49% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"| |- |align="left"|Amherst |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="right"|35 |align="right"| |align="left"|<ref name=twsZe22/> |- |align="left"|Lafayette |align="right"|26% |align="right"|27% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"| |- |align="left"|U. North Carolina |align="right"|54% |align="right"|53% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"|<small>Chapel Hill campus</small> |- |align="left"|U. Iowa |align="right"|33% |align="right"|34% |align="right"|0 |align="right"|0 |align="left"| |- |align="left"|Connecticut College |align="right"|29% |align="right"|31% |align="right"|44 |align="right"|0 |align="left"| |- |align="left"|Colorado College |align="right"|33% |align="right"|37% |align="right"| |align="right"| |align="left"| |- |} ::Note: the ''yield'' is the percent of students offered admission who commit to enrolling. ::Note: ''Wait list acceptances'' are the number of wait-listed applicants who were eventually offered admission, and accepted the offer. ::Source for data: Jacques Steinberg of ''[[The New York Times]]'', May 2010<ref name=twsZe23/>
==See also== * [[College admissions in the United States]] * [[Transfer admissions in the United States]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox organization |name = Youth for Heritage Foundation |image = Logo_-_Youth_for_Heritage_Foundation.png |image_border = |size = <!-- default 200 --> |alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> |caption = |map = <!-- optional --> |msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 200px --> |malt = <!-- map alt text --> |mcaption = <!-- optional --> |abbreviation = YfHF |formation = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|2014|01|26}} |extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> |type = [[Non-governmental organizations|NGO]] |founder = [[Vikramjit Singh Rooprai]] |status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> |purpose = Heritage Awareness and Promotion |headquarters = New Delhi |location = |coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> |region_served = |membership = |language = <!-- official languages --> |leader_title = <!-- Chairman --> |leader_name = <!-- Vikramjit Singh Rooprai --> |main_organ = <!-- Governing Council --> |parent_organization = <!-- if one --> |affiliations = <!-- if any --> |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.youthforheritage.org/ Youth for Heritage Foundation] |remarks = }}
The '''Youth for Heritage Foundation''' is a non-profit non-governmental organization registered under the Societies Registration Act, 1860. It was started as a hobby project in October 2009 and became popular over time.
==History== In October 2009, [[Vikramjit Singh Rooprai]], an information technology consultant and social media guru went on a personal site-seeing trip to monuments in Delhi. He found many sites, for which, there was no reference available online. He launched a project named Didar-i-Dilli and started gathering information about Delhi's heritage. The information was made public via his website [http://www.monumentsofdelhi.com monumentsofdelhi.com] later that year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/299132/delhiites-take-walks-big-way.html|title=Delhiites take to walks in a big way|author=|date=|work=Deccan Herald}}</ref>
In October 2010, Vikramjit formed an online club named Delhi Heritage Awareness Club. This club started heritage walks with a small group of people. Upon suggestions from members, the club was renamed The Heritage Photography Club. In less than 7 years, they had 21,000 members on Facebook and became one of the largest repository of photographs of monuments from across India.
In 2013, the Heritage Photography Club started organizing heritage talks at monuments. These talks were branded Heritage Durbars. Initially, these durbars (sessions) were held at various monuments in Delhi. In 2014, the club was invited by [[India Habitat Centre]] to conduct these sessions at one of their auditoriums. In 2014, the body was registered under the Societies Registration Act as Youth for Heritage Foundation. Rooprai was the founding chairman.
==Activities== Youth for Heritage Foundation is involved in heritage promotion and awareness by educational institutions, corporations, and individuals.
===The Heritage Photography Club=== The largest arm of Youth for Heritage Foundation is the Delhi Heritage Photography Club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://littleblackbookdelhi.com/hobby-run-20-hobby-clubs-delhi/|title=A Hobby Run - 8 Hobby Clubs in Delhi|author=Rashi Wadhera|date=|work=Little Black Book Delhi}}</ref> In December 2016, the club was renamed The Heritage Photography Club. Regular heritage photo-walks are organized at monuments across India. The focus remains on educating people about the lesser known aspects, architecture and history of the sites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timescity.com/blog/10-guided-tours-explore-delhi/|title=10 Guided Tours To Explore Delhi|author=|date=|work=What's Hot!}}</ref>
===Heritage Durbars=== Youth for Heritage Foundation started Heritage Talks in 2013. First talk was held at [[Zafar Mahal (Mehrauli)|Zafar Mahal]] in [[Mehrauli]] on [[Sufism]]. Since 2014, these talks are being organized in Casuarina and Gulmohar Hall of India Habitat Centre. Every month, a new speaker is identified and a new topic is presented to audience. Personalities like [[Pushpesh Pant]], [[KK Muhammed]], [[Raza Rumi]], Feisal Alkazi, Sohail Hashmi, R.V. Smith, Dr. Sharif Hussain Qasemi and D. N. Chaudhuri have spoken through this platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/clio-on-a-sunny-afternoon/article5670671.ece|title=Clio on a sunny afternoon|author=R. V. SMITH|date=|work=The Hindu}}</ref>
===Heritage Photography Contests and Exhibitions=== Under the banner of the Delhi Heritage Photography Club, Youth for Heritage Foundation organizes annual exhibitions. A contest is organized for the selection of images and winning shots are exhibited at the venue. The following exhibitions have been organized by the club: * 2012 - 'Monuments of Delhi' at India Habitat Centre <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Delhi/a-helping-hand-for-heritage/article4081579.ece|title=A helping hand for heritage|author=Sohail Hashmi|date=|work=The Hindu}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/294558/amateurs-capture-delhis-history.html|title=Amateurs capture Delhi's history|author=|date=|work=Deccan Herald}}</ref> * 2013 - 'Monuments of Delhi (Night) - at India Habitat Centre <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/373671/lens-eye-view-capitals-history.html|title=Len's eye view of Capital's history|author=|date=|work=Deccan Herald}}</ref> * 2014 - 'Forgotten Heritage - Delhi' at India Habitat Centre, Red Fort in association with [[Archaeological Survey of India]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/cities/delhi/of-amateur-photographers-and-less-known-monuments/|title=Of amateur photographers and less-known monuments|author=|date=17 April 2014|work=The Indian Express}}</ref> and 'The Qutub' at Qutub Minar
===Heritage Ambassadors=== The foundation constituted a panel to identify heritage lovers operating within their geographic regions, promoting or protecting Heritage. The first Heritage Ambassador award was given on World Heritage Day, 18 April 2015 to Abdul Aziz Rajput of [[Bijapur]] for his service to community.
===Monument Protection=== Youth for Heritage Foundation has been instrumental in protecting the endangered heritage sites. The group contributed to saving the historic Lal Mahal<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/a-tear-for-lal-mahal/article4844523.ece|title=A tear for Lal Mahal|last=Smith|first=R.V.|date=|work=The Hindu}}</ref> in Nizamuddin Basti with their #SaveLalMahal campaign. This structure is said to be the oldest structure in India having a true dome and a ''Taikhana''. The structure was being demolished by its owners. Youth for Heritage Foundation raised a petition and upon intervention from different government bodies, the demolition was stopped.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/915564/petition-launched-against-demolition-of-lal-mahal#|title=Petition Launched Against Demolition of Lal Mahal|date=|work=Artinfo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://brownpaperbag.in/delhi/intel/savelalmahal-my-game-is-red/|title=Brown Paper Bag - #Savelalmahal: My Game is Red|author=|date=|work=Brown Paper Bag}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2013/06/20/in-delhi-developers-imperil-islamic-palace/|title=In Delhi, Developers Imperil Islamic Palace|author=|date=|work=WSJ}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.monumentsofdelhi.com/ Monuments of Delhi] * [http://www.dhpc.in/ The Heritage Photography Club]
{{DEFAULTSORT:INTACH}} [[Category:Youth organisations based in India]] [[Category:Heritage organizations]] [[Category:Organisations based in Delhi]] [[Category:Cultural heritage of India]] [[Category:History organisations based in India]]
